**Leeds** [/liːdz/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:En-uk-Leeds.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/07/En-uk-Leeds.ogg "En-uk-
Leeds.ogg"))[5] is a city in [West Yorkshire](/wiki/West_Yorkshire "West
Yorkshire"), England. [Historically](/wiki/Historic_counties_of_England
"Historic counties of England") in Yorkshire's [West
Riding](/wiki/West_Riding_of_Yorkshire "West Riding of Yorkshire"), _Leeds_
can be traced to the 5th century name for a wooded area of the [Kingdom of
Elmet](/wiki/Elmet "Elmet"). The name has been applied to many administrative
entities over the centuries. It changed from being the name of a small
manorial borough in the 13th century, through several incarnations, to being
the name attached to the present metropolitan borough. In the 17th and 18th
centuries Leeds became a major centre for the production and trading of wool.

During the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial
Revolution"), Leeds developed into a major [mill town](/wiki/Mill_town "Mill
town"); wool was the dominant industry, but [flax](/wiki/Flax "Flax"),
engineering, [iron foundries](/wiki/Iron_foundry "Iron foundry"), printing,
and other industries were important.[6] From being a compact market town in
the valley of the [River Aire](/wiki/River_Aire "River Aire"), in the 16th
century, Leeds expanded and absorbed the surrounding villages to become a
populous urban centre by the mid-20th century. Leeds has a population of
around 781,700 (2016), making it the [third-most populous British
city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_United_Kingdom "List of cities in the United
Kingdom") after [London](/wiki/London "London") and
[Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham").[7] The city lies within the
United Kingdom's [fourth-most populous urban
area](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_United_Kingdom "List of
metropolitan areas in the United Kingdom"), with a population of 2.4
million.[8]

The economy of Leeds is the most diverse of all of the UK's main employment
centres and has seen the fastest rate of private-sector jobs growth of any UK
city. It also has the highest ratio of private to public sector jobs of all
the UK's Core Cities, with 77% of its workforce working in the private sector.
Leeds has the third-largest jobs total by local authority area, with 480,000
in employment and self-employment at the beginning of 2015.[4] Leeds is home
to over 109,000 companies generating 5% of England's total economic output of
£60.5 billion,[9] and is also ranked as a [gamma world
city](/wiki/Global_city#GaWC_study "Global city") by the [Globalization and
World Cities Research
Network](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization
and World Cities Research Network").[10] Leeds is considered the cultural,
financial and commercial heart of the [West Yorkshire Urban
Area](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Urban_Area "West Yorkshire Urban
Area").[11][12][13] Leeds is served by four universities, and has the fourth
largest student population in the country and the country's [fourth largest
urban economy](/wiki/List_of_UK_cities_by_GVA "List of UK cities by GVA").[14]

After London, Leeds is the largest legal and financial centre in the
UK,[4][15] with the financial and insurance services industry worth £13
billion to the Leeds economy.[4][16][17] with more than 30 national and
international banks located in the city including the only subsidiary office
of the [Bank of England](/wiki/Bank_of_England "Bank of England") in the UK
.[15] Leeds is also the UK's third largest manufacturing centre with around
1,800 firms and 39,000 employees, Leeds manufacturing firms account for 8.8%
of total employment in the city and is worth over £7 billion to the local
economy.[18] The largest sub-sectors are engineering, printing and publishing,
food and drink, chemicals and medical technology.[19] The city is the home of
several firsts, including the oldest surviving film in existence, _[Roundhay
Garden Scene](/wiki/Roundhay_Garden_Scene "Roundhay Garden Scene")_ (1888) and
the 1767 invention of [soda water](/wiki/Soda_water "Soda water"), the
defining component of most [soft drinks](/wiki/Soft_drink "Soft
drink").[20][21]

Outside London, Leeds has the third busiest railway station [22] and tenth-
busiest airport in terms of passenger numbers in England.[23] Public
transport, rail and road communications networks in the region are focused on
Leeds. Its assigned role in the [Leeds City Region](/wiki/Leeds_City_Region
"Leeds City Region") partnership recognises the city's importance to regional
economic development, and the second phase of [High Speed
2](/wiki/High_Speed_2 "High Speed 2") plans to connect Leeds to London via
[East Midlands Hub](/wiki/East_Midlands_Hub_railway_station "East Midlands Hub
railway station") and [Sheffield Meadowhall](/wiki/Meadowhall_Interchange
"Meadowhall Interchange").

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of Leeds](/wiki/History_of_Leeds "History of Leeds")

### Toponymy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Toponymy")]

The name _Leeds_ derives from the old Brythonic word _Ladenses_ meaning
"people of the fast-flowing river", in reference to the [River
Aire](/wiki/River_Aire "River Aire") that flows through the city.[24] This
name originally referred to the forested area covering most of the [Brythonic
kingdom of Elmet](/wiki/Elmet "Elmet"), which existed during the 5th century
into the early 7th century.[25]

[Bede](/wiki/Bede "Bede") states in the fourteenth chapter of his
_[Ecclesiastical History](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_History_of_the_English_People
"Ecclesiastical History of the English People")_ , in a discussion of an altar
surviving from a church erected by [Edwin of
Northumbria](/wiki/Edwin_of_Northumbria "Edwin of Northumbria"), that it is
located in _...regione quae vocatur Loidis_ (Latin, "the region which is
called Loidis"). An inhabitant of Leeds is locally known as a
_[Loiner](/wiki/Loiner "Loiner")_ , a word of uncertain origin.[26] The term
_Leodensian_ is also used, from the city's Latin name.

The name _Leeds_ has also been explained as a derivative of
[Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") _lloed_ , meaning simply 'a
place'.[27]

### Economic development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Economic development")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/The_Mint%2C_Granary_Wharf%2C_Leeds_%285385775582%29.jpg/220px-
The_Mint%2C_Granary_Wharf%2C_Leeds_%285385775582%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Mint,_Granary_Wharf,_Leeds_\(5385775582\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Mint,_Granary_Wharf,_Leeds_\(5385775582\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [Leeds and Liverpool Canal](/wiki/Leeds_and_Liverpool_Canal "Leeds and
Liverpool Canal") at [Granary Wharf](/wiki/Granary_Wharf "Granary Wharf")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Inside_the_Corn_Exchange_2_-_Leeds.jpg/220px-
Inside_the_Corn_Exchange_2_-_Leeds.jpg)](/wiki/File:Inside_the_Corn_Exchange_2_-_Leeds.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Inside_the_Corn_Exchange_2_-_Leeds.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Leeds Corn Exchange](/wiki/Leeds_Corn_Exchange "Leeds Corn Exchange")
opened in 1864

Leeds developed as a [market town](/wiki/Market_town "Market town") in the
[Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") as part of the local
agricultural economy. Before the [Industrial
Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution"), it became a
co-ordination centre for the manufacture of woollen cloth, and white
[broadcloth](/wiki/Broadcloth "Broadcloth") was traded at its [White Cloth
Hall](/wiki/White_Cloth_Hall "White Cloth Hall").[28]

Leeds handled one sixth of England's export trade in 1770.[29] Growth,
initially in textiles, was accelerated by the building of the [Aire and Calder
Navigation](/wiki/Aire_and_Calder_Navigation "Aire and Calder Navigation") in
1699 and the [Leeds and Liverpool Canal](/wiki/Leeds_and_Liverpool_Canal
"Leeds and Liverpool Canal") in 1816.[30]

The railway network constructed around Leeds, starting with the [Leeds and
Selby Railway](/wiki/Leeds_and_Selby_Railway "Leeds and Selby Railway") in
1834, provided improved communications with national markets and,
significantly for its development, an east-west connection with
[Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester") and the ports of
[Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool") and [Hull](/wiki/Kingston_upon_Hull
"Kingston upon Hull") giving improved access to international markets.[31]
Alongside technological advances and industrial expansion, Leeds retained an
interest in trading in agricultural commodities, with the [Corn
Exchange](/wiki/Leeds_Corn_Exchange "Leeds Corn Exchange") opening in 1864.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Joseph_Rhodes_-
_Leeds_from_the_Meadows.jpg/220px-Joseph_Rhodes_-
_Leeds_from_the_Meadows.jpg)](/wiki/File:Joseph_Rhodes_-
_Leeds_from_the_Meadows.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Joseph_Rhodes_-_Leeds_from_the_Meadows.jpg "Enlarge")

_Leeds from the Meadows_ by Joseph Rhodes, 1825.

[Marshall's Mill](/wiki/Marshall%27s_Mill "Marshall's Mill") was one of the
first of many factories constructed in Leeds from around 1790 when the most
significant were woollen finishing and flax mills.[32] Manufacturing
diversified by 1914 to printing, engineering, chemicals and clothing
manufacture.[33] Decline in manufacturing during the 1930s was temporarily
reversed by a switch to producing military uniforms and munitions during World
War II. However, by the 1970s, the clothing industry was in irreversible
decline, facing cheap foreign competition.[34] The contemporary economy has
been shaped by [Leeds City Council](/wiki/Leeds_City_Council "Leeds City
Council")'s vision of building a '24-hour European city' and 'capital of the
north'.[35] The city has developed from the decay of the post-industrial era
to become a telephone banking centre, connected to the electronic
infrastructure of the modern global economy.[35] There has been growth in the
corporate and legal sectors,[36] and increased local affluence has led to an
expanding retail sector, including the [luxury goods](/wiki/Luxury_goods
"Luxury goods") market.[37]

[Leeds City Region Enterprise Zone](/wiki/Leeds_City_Region_Enterprise_Zone
"Leeds City Region Enterprise Zone") was launched in April 2012 to promote
development in four sites along the [A63](/wiki/A63_road "A63 road") East
Leeds Link Road.[38]

Leeds was a manor and township in the large ancient parish of _Leeds St Peter_
, in the [Skyrack](/wiki/Skyrack "Skyrack") [wapentake](/wiki/Wapentake
"Wapentake") of the [West Riding](/wiki/West_Riding_of_Yorkshire "West Riding
of Yorkshire") of [Yorkshire](/wiki/Yorkshire "Yorkshire").[40] The Borough of
Leeds was created in 1207, when Maurice Paynel, lord of the manor, granted a
charter to a small area of the manor, close to the river crossing, in what is
now the city centre. Four centuries later, the inhabitants petitioned [Charles
I](/wiki/Charles_I_of_England "Charles I of England") for a charter of
incorporation, which was granted in 1626. The new charter incorporated the
entire parish, including all eleven townships, as the [Borough of
Leeds](/wiki/County_Borough_of_Leeds "County Borough of Leeds") and withdrew
the earlier charter. [Improvement
commissioners](/wiki/Improvement_commissioners "Improvement commissioners")
were set up in 1755 for paving, lighting, and cleansing of the main streets,
including [Briggate](/wiki/Briggate,_Leeds "Briggate, Leeds") and further
powers were added in 1790 to improve the water supply.[41]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Leeds_Town_Hall%2C_General_Election_results.jpg/220px-
Leeds_Town_Hall%2C_General_Election_results.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds_Town_Hall,_General_Election_results.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_Town_Hall,_General_Election_results.jpg "Enlarge")

A crowd gathers outside Leeds Town Hall during the 1880 general elections.

The borough corporation was reformed under the provisions of [Municipal
Corporations Act 1835](/wiki/Municipal_Corporations_Act_1835 "Municipal
Corporations Act 1835"). [Leeds Borough Police](/wiki/Leeds_City_Police "Leeds
City Police") force was formed in 1836, and [Leeds Town
Hall](/wiki/Leeds_Town_Hall "Leeds Town Hall") was completed by the
corporation in 1858. In 1866, Leeds and each of the other townships in the
borough became [civil parishs](/wiki/Civil_parish "Civil parish"). The borough
became a [county borough](/wiki/County_borough "County borough") in 1889,
giving it independence from the newly formed West Riding County Council and it
gained [city status](/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom "City status in
the United Kingdom") in 1893. In 1904 the Leeds parish absorbed
[Beeston](/wiki/Beeston,_Leeds "Beeston, Leeds"), [Chapel
Allerton](/wiki/Chapel_Allerton "Chapel Allerton"),
[Farnley](/wiki/Farnley,_West_Yorkshire "Farnley, West Yorkshire"),
[Headingley cum Burley](/wiki/Headingley_cum_Burley "Headingley cum Burley")
and [Potternewton](/wiki/Potternewton "Potternewton") from within the borough.
In the twentieth century the county borough initiated a series of significant
territorial expansions, growing from 21,593 acres (87.38 km2) in 1911 to
40,612 acres (164.35 km2) in 1961.[42] In 1912 the parish and county borough
of Leeds absorbed [Leeds Rural District](/wiki/Leeds_Rural_District "Leeds
Rural District"), consisting of the parishes of [Roundhay](/wiki/Roundhay
"Roundhay") and [Seacroft](/wiki/Seacroft "Seacroft"); and
[Shadwell](/wiki/Shadwell,_West_Yorkshire "Shadwell, West Yorkshire"), which
had been part of Wetherby Rural District. On 1 April 1925, the parish of Leeds
was expanded to cover the whole borough.[40]

The county borough was abolished on 1 April 1974, and its former area was
combined with that of the municipal boroughs of
[Morley](/wiki/Municipal_Borough_of_Morley "Municipal Borough of Morley") and
[Pudsey](/wiki/Municipal_Borough_of_Pudsey "Municipal Borough of Pudsey"); the
urban districts of [Aireborough](/wiki/Aireborough_Urban_District "Aireborough
Urban District"), [Horsforth](/wiki/Horsforth_Urban_District "Horsforth Urban
District"), [Otley](/wiki/Otley_Urban_District "Otley Urban District"),
[Garforth](/wiki/Garforth_Urban_District "Garforth Urban District") and
[Rothwell](/wiki/Rothwell_Urban_District_\(Yorkshire\) "Rothwell Urban
District \(Yorkshire\)"); and parts of the rural districts of
[Tadcaster](/wiki/Tadcaster_Rural_District "Tadcaster Rural District"),
[Wetherby](/wiki/Wetherby_Rural_District "Wetherby Rural District"), and
[Wharfedale](/wiki/Wharfedale_Rural_District "Wharfedale Rural District").[43]
This area formed a metropolitan district in the county of [West
Yorkshire](/wiki/West_Yorkshire "West Yorkshire"). It gained both borough and
city status and is known as the [City of Leeds](/wiki/City_of_Leeds "City of
Leeds"). Initially, local government services were provided by [Leeds City
Council](/wiki/Leeds_City_Council "Leeds City Council") and [West Yorkshire
County Council](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_County_Council "West Yorkshire County
Council"). When the county council was abolished in 1986, the city council
absorbed its functions, and some powers passed to organisations such as the
[West Yorkshire Passenger Transport
Authority](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Passenger_Transport_Authority "West Yorkshire
Passenger Transport Authority"). From 1988 two run-down and derelict areas
close to the [city centre](/wiki/Leeds_city_centre "Leeds city centre") were
designated for regeneration and became the responsibility of [Leeds
Development Corporation](/wiki/Leeds_Development_Corporation "Leeds
Development Corporation"), outside the planning remit of the city council.[44]
Planning powers were restored to the local authority in 1995 when the
development corporation was wound up.

### Suburban growth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Suburban growth")]

[![This map shows central Leeds and \(clockwise from top left\) the developing
suburbs of Hyde Park, Woodhouse, Sheepscar, New Leeds, Cross Green, Hunslet,
Holbeck, Wortley, Armley and
Burley.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Leeds_1866_by_J_Bartholemew_edited.jpg/220px-
Leeds_1866_by_J_Bartholemew_edited.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds_1866_by_J_Bartholemew_edited.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_1866_by_J_Bartholemew_edited.jpg "Enlarge")

1866 map of Leeds

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/James_Valentine_The_Briggate_Leeds.jpg/220px-
James_Valentine_The_Briggate_Leeds.jpg)](/wiki/File:James_Valentine_The_Briggate_Leeds.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:James_Valentine_The_Briggate_Leeds.jpg "Enlarge")

19th century [Briggate, Leeds](/wiki/Briggate,_Leeds "Briggate, Leeds")

In 1801, 42% of the population of Leeds lived outside the township, in the
wider borough. [Cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") outbreaks in 1832 and 1849
caused the authorities to address the problems of drainage, sanitation, and
water supply. Water was pumped from the River Wharfe, but by 1860 it was too
heavily polluted to be usable. Following the Leeds Waterworks Act of 1867
three reservoirs were built at Lindley Wood, Swinsty, and Fewston in the
Washburn Valley north of Leeds.[45]

Residential growth occurred in Holbeck and Hunslet from 1801 to 1851, but, as
these townships became industrialised new areas were favoured for middle class
housing.[46] Land south of the river was developed primarily for industry and
secondarily for [back-to-back](/wiki/Back-to-back_houses "Back-to-back
houses") workers' dwellings. The Leeds Improvement Act 1866 sought to improve
the quality of working class housing by restricting the number of homes that
could be built in a single terrace.[47]

Holbeck and Leeds formed a continuous built-up area by 1858, with Hunslet
nearly meeting them.[48] In the latter half of the nineteenth century,
population growth in Hunslet, Armley, and Wortley outstripped that of Leeds.
When pollution became a problem, the wealthier residents left the industrial
conurbation to live in Headingley, Potternewton and Chapel Allerton which led
to a 50% increase in the population of Headingley and Burley from 1851 to
1861. The middle-class flight from the industrial areas led to development
beyond the borough at Roundhay and Adel.[48] The introduction of the [electric
tramway](/wiki/Leeds_Tramway "Leeds Tramway") led to intensification of
development in Headingley and Potternewton and expansion outside the borough
into Roundhay.[49]

Two private gas supply companies were taken over by the corporation in 1870,
and the municipal supply provided street lighting and cheaper gas to homes.
From the early 1880s, the Yorkshire House-to-House Electricity Company
supplied electricity to Leeds until it was purchased by Leeds Corporation and
became a municipal supply.[50]

[Slum clearance](/wiki/Slum_clearance "Slum clearance") and rebuilding began
in Leeds during the [Inter-war period](/wiki/Inter-war_period "Inter-war
period") when over 18,000 houses were built by the council on 24 estates in
[Cross Gates](/wiki/Cross_Gates "Cross Gates"), Middleton, Gipton, Belle Isle
and Halton Moor. The slums of [Quarry Hill](/wiki/Quarry_Hill,_Leeds "Quarry
Hill, Leeds") were replaced by the innovative Quarry Hill flats, which were
demolished in 1975. Another 36,000 houses were built by private sector
builders, creating suburbs in Gledhow, Moortown, Alwoodley, Roundhay, Colton,
Whitkirk, [Oakwood](/wiki/Oakwood,_Leeds "Oakwood, Leeds"), Weetwood, and
Adel. After 1949 a further 30,000 sub-standard houses were demolished by the
council and replaced by 151 medium-rise and high-rise blocks of council flats
in estates at Seacroft, Armley Heights, Tinshill, and Brackenwood.[51]

Leeds has seen great expenditure on regenerating the city, attracting in
investments and flagship projects,[52] as found in [Leeds city
centre](/wiki/Leeds_city_centre "Leeds city centre"). Many developments
boasting luxurious penthouse apartments have been built close to the city
centre.

Leeds_in_West_Yorkshire.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds_in_West_Yorkshire.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_in_West_Yorkshire.jpg "Enlarge")

Map of Leeds in West Yorkshire

[![The canalised River Aire flows from the Dark Arches under Leeds's main
railway station towards the bottom of the picture. To the left of the river is
the lock which links the river with the Leeds and Liverpool Canal. To the

[](/wiki/File:River_Aire_waterfront,_Leeds_001.jpg "Enlarge")

River Aire in Leeds

Leeds is located 190 miles (310 km) north-northwest of
[London](/wiki/Central_London "Central London"), on the valley of the [River
Aire](/wiki/River_Aire "River Aire") in the eastern foothills of the
[Pennines](/wiki/Pennines "Pennines"). The city centre lies in a narrow
section of the Aire Valley at about 206 feet (63 m) [above sea
level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level"); while the district
ranges from 1,115 feet (340 m) in the far west on the slopes of [Ilkley
Moor](/wiki/Ilkley_Moor "Ilkley Moor") to about 33 feet (10 m) where the
rivers Aire and Wharfe cross the eastern boundary. The centre of Leeds is part
of a continuously built-up area extending to Pudsey, Bramley, Horsforth,
Alwoodley, Seacroft, Middleton and Morley.[53]

Leeds has the second [highest
population](/wiki/List_of_English_districts_by_population "List of English
districts by population") of any local authority district in the UK (after
[Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham")), and the second [greatest
area](/wiki/List_of_English_districts_by_area "List of English districts by
area") of any English [metropolitan district](/wiki/Metropolitan_borough
"Metropolitan borough") (after
[Doncaster](/wiki/Metropolitan_Borough_of_Doncaster "Metropolitan Borough of
Doncaster")), extending 15 miles (24 km) from east to west, and 13 miles (21
km) from north to south. The northern boundary follows the [River
Wharfe](/wiki/River_Wharfe "River Wharfe") for several miles, but it crosses
the river to include the part of Otley which lies north of the river.

The city centre is less than twenty miles (32 km) from the [Yorkshire Dales
National Park](/wiki/Yorkshire_Dales "Yorkshire Dales"),[54] which has some of
the most spectacular scenery and countryside in the UK.[55] Inner and southern
areas of Leeds lie on a layer of coal measure sandstones forming the
[Yorkshire Coalfield](/wiki/South_Yorkshire_Coalfield "South Yorkshire
Coalfield"). To the north parts are built on older sandstone and gritstones
and to the east it extends into the magnesian limestone belt.[32][56][57] The
[land use](/wiki/Land_use "Land use") in the central areas of Leeds is
overwhelmingly urban.[53]

Attempts to define the exact geographic meaning of Leeds lead to a variety of
concepts of its extent, varying by context include the area of the [city
centre](/wiki/Leeds_city_centre "Leeds city centre"), the urban sprawl, the
administrative boundaries, and the [functional region](/wiki/Functional_region
"Functional region").[58]

> Leeds is much more a generalised concept place name in inverted commas, it
> is the city, but it is also the commuter villages and the region as well.
>
> — Brian Thompson, A History of Modern Leeds[58]

[Leeds city centre](/wiki/Leeds_city_centre "Leeds city centre") is contained
within the [Leeds Inner Ring Road](/wiki/Leeds_Inner_Ring_Road "Leeds Inner
Ring Road"), formed from parts of the [A58 road](/wiki/A58_road "A58 road"),
[A61 road](/wiki/A61_road "A61 road"), [A64 road](/wiki/A64_road "A64 road"),
[A643 road](/wiki/A643_road "A643 road") and the [M621
motorway](/wiki/M621_motorway "M621 motorway").
[Briggate](/wiki/Briggate,_Leeds "Briggate, Leeds"), the principal north-south
shopping street, is pedestrianised and Queen Victoria Street, a part of the
[Victoria Quarter](/wiki/Victoria_Quarter "Victoria Quarter"), is enclosed
under a glass roof. [Millennium Square](/wiki/Millennium_Square_\(Leeds\)
"Millennium Square \(Leeds\)") is a significant urban focal point. The [Leeds
postcode area](/wiki/LS_postcode_area "LS postcode area") covers most of the
City of Leeds[59] and is almost entirely made up of the Leeds [post
town](/wiki/Post_town "Post town").[60] Otley, Wetherby, Tadcaster, Pudsey and
Ilkley are separate post towns within the postcode area.[60] Aside from the
built up area of Leeds itself, there are a [number of suburbs and
exurbs](/wiki/List_of_places_in_Leeds "List of places in Leeds") within the
district.

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Climate")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Park_Square_and_Leeds_Town_Hall_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_183544.jpg/220px-Park_Square_and_Leeds_Town_Hall_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_183544.jpg)](/wiki/File:Park_Square_and_Leeds_Town_Hall_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_183544.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Park_Square_and_Leeds_Town_Hall_-_geograph.org.uk_-_183544.jpg
"Enlarge")

Sunny early-June 2006 day at [Park Square](/wiki/Park_Square,_Leeds "Park
Square, Leeds")

Leeds has a climate that is [oceanic](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic
climate"), and influenced by the [Pennines](/wiki/Pennines "Pennines").
Summers are usually mild, with moderate rainfall, while winters are chilly,
cloudy with occasional snow and frost. The nearest official weather recording
station is at Bingley, some twenty kilometres away at a higher altitude.[61]

Situated on the eastern side of the [Pennines](/wiki/Pennines "Pennines"),
Leeds is among the drier cities in the United Kingdom, with an annual rainfall
of 660 mm (25.98 in).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The last reported tornado occurred on 14 September 2006, causing uprooted
trees and signal failures at [Leeds City railway
station](/wiki/Leeds_railway_station "Leeds railway station").[62]

### Green belt[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Green belt")]

Further information: [South and West Yorkshire Green
Belt](/wiki/South_and_West_Yorkshire_Green_Belt "South and West Yorkshire
Green Belt")

Leeds is within a [green belt](/wiki/Green_belt_\(United_Kingdom\) "Green belt
\(United Kingdom\)") region that extends into the wider surrounding counties,
and is in place to reduce [urban sprawl](/wiki/Urban_sprawl "Urban sprawl"),
prevent the settlements in the West Yorkshire conurbation from further
convergence, protect the identity of outlying communities, encourage
[brownfield](/wiki/Brownfield "Brownfield") reuse, and preserve nearby
countryside. This is achieved by restricting inappropriate development within
the designated areas, and imposing stricter conditions on permitted
building.[63]

Over 60% of the Leeds district is [green belt](/wiki/Green_belt_\(UK\) "Green
belt \(UK\)") land and it surrounds the settlement, preventing further sprawl
towards nearby communities. Larger outlying towns and villages are exempt from
the green belt area. However, smaller villages, hamlets and rural areas are
'washed over' by the designation. The green belt was first adopted in
1960,[63] and the size in the borough in 2017 amounted to some 33,970 hectares
(339.7 km2; 131.2 sq mi).[64]

A subsidiary aim of the green belt is to encourage recreation and leisure
interests,[63] with rural landscape features, greenfield areas and facilities
including Temple Newsam Park and House with golf course, Rothwell Country
Park, Middleton Park, Kirkstall Abbey ruins and surrounding park, Bedquilts
recreation grounds, Waterloo lake, Roundhay castle and park, and Morwick,
Cobble and Elmete Halls.

At the time of the [United Kingdom Census
2001](/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2001 "United Kingdom Census 2001"), the
Leeds urban subdivision occupied an area of 109 square kilometres (42 sq mi)
and had a population of 443,247; making it the fourth most populous urban
subdivision within England and the fifth largest within the United Kingdom.
The population density was 4,066 inhabitants per square kilometre (10,530/sq
mi), slightly higher than the rest of the [West Yorkshire Urban
Area](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Urban_Area "West Yorkshire Urban Area"). It
accounts for 20% of the area and 62% of the population of the City of Leeds.
The population of the urban subdivision had a 100 to 93.1 female–male
ratio.[67] Of those over 16 years old, 39.4% were single (never married) and
35.4% married for the first time.[68] The urban subdivision's 188,890
households included 35% one-person, 27.9% married couples living together,
8.8% were co-habiting couples, and 5.7% single parents with their children.
Leeds is the largest component of the West Yorkshire Urban Area[53] and is
counted by [Eurostat](/wiki/Eurostat "Eurostat") as part of the Leeds-Bradford
[Larger Urban Zone](/wiki/Larger_Urban_Zones "Larger Urban Zones"). The Leeds
[Travel to Work Area](/wiki/Travel_to_Work_Area "Travel to Work Area") in 2001
included all of the City of Leeds, a northern strip of the City of Bradford,
the eastern part of Kirklees, and a section of southern North Yorkshire; it
occupies 751 square kilometres (290 sq mi).

### Metropolitan
district[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section:
Metropolitan district")]

At the [2011 UK census](/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011 "United Kingdom
Census 2011"), the district had a total population of 751,500, representing a
5% growth since the last census of 2001.[69] Of the 301,614 households in
Leeds in the 2001 census, 33.3% were married couples living together, 31.6%
were one-person households, 9.0% were [co-habiting](/wiki/Cohabitation
"Cohabitation") couples and 9.8% were lone parents, following a similar trend
to the rest of England.[70] The population density was 1,967/km2 (5,090/sq
mi)[70] and for every 100 females, there were 93.5 males.

Leeds is a diverse city with over 75 ethnic groups, and with minority ethnic
populations representing just under 11.6% of the total population.[69]
According to figures from the [2011 census](/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011
"United Kingdom Census 2011"), 85.0% of the population was
[White](/wiki/White_people "White people") (81.1% [White
British](/wiki/White_British "White British"), 0.9% [White
Irish](/wiki/Irish_migration_to_Great_Britain "Irish migration to Great
Britain"), 0.1% [Gypsy](/wiki/Gypsy_\(term\) "Gypsy \(term\)") or [Irish
Traveller](/wiki/Irish_Traveller "Irish Traveller"), 2.9% [Other
White](/wiki/Other_White "Other White")), 2.7% of [mixed
race](/wiki/Mixed_\(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category\) "Mixed \(United
Kingdom ethnicity category\)") (1.2% White and Black Caribbean, 0.3% White and
Black African, 0.7% White and Asian, 0.5% Other Mixed), 7.7%
[Asian](/wiki/British_Asian "British Asian") (2.1%
[Indian](/wiki/British_Indian "British Indian"), 3.0%
[Pakistani](/wiki/British_Pakistanis "British Pakistanis"), 0.6%
[Bangladeshi](/wiki/British_Bangladeshi "British Bangladeshi"), 0.8%
[Chinese](/wiki/British_Chinese "British Chinese"), 1.2% Other Asian), 3.5%
[Black](/wiki/Black_British "Black British") (2.0% African, 0.9%
[Caribbean](/wiki/British_African-Caribbean_people "British African-Caribbean
people"), 0.6% [Other Black](/wiki/Other_Black "Other Black")), 0.5%
[Arab](/wiki/British_Arab "British Arab") and 0.6% of other ethnic
heritage.[71]

The majority of people in Leeds identify themselves as Christian.[72] The
proportion of Muslims (3.0% of the population) is average for the country.[72]
Leeds has the third-largest community of Jews in the United Kingdom, after
those of London and Manchester. The areas of [Alwoodley](/wiki/Alwoodley
"Alwoodley") and [Moortown](/wiki/Moortown,_West_Yorkshire "Moortown, West
Yorkshire") contain sizeable Jewish populations.[73] 16.8% of Leeds residents
in the 2001 census declared themselves as having "no religion", which is
broadly in line with the figure for the whole of the UK (also 8.1% "religion
not stated"). The crime rate in Leeds is well above the national average, like
many other English major cities.[74][75] In July 2006, the [think
tank](/wiki/Think_tank "Think tank") [Reform](/wiki/Reform_\(think_tank\)
"Reform \(think tank\)") calculated rates of crime for different offences and
has related this to populations of major urban areas (defined as towns over
100,000 population). Leeds was 11th in this rating (excluding London boroughs,
23rd including London boroughs).[76] Total recorded crime in Leeds fell by 45%
between 2002/03 and 2011/12.[69]

## Government[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Government")]

See also: [City of Leeds](/wiki/City_of_Leeds "City of Leeds")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Civic_Hall_Leeds_West_Yorkshire.jpg/220px-
Civic_Hall_Leeds_West_Yorkshire.jpg)](/wiki/File:Civic_Hall_Leeds_West_Yorkshire.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Civic_Hall_Leeds_West_Yorkshire.jpg "Enlarge")

[Leeds Civic Hall](/wiki/Leeds_Civic_Hall "Leeds Civic Hall") is the seat of
local government.

The [City of Leeds](/wiki/City_of_Leeds "City of Leeds") is the [local
government district](/wiki/Districts_of_England "Districts of England")
covering Leeds, and the local authority is [Leeds City
Council](/wiki/Leeds_City_Council "Leeds City Council"). The council is
composed of 99 councillors, three for each of the district's
[wards](/wiki/Wards_of_the_United_Kingdom "Wards of the United Kingdom").
Elections are held three years out of four, on the first Thursday of May. One
third of the councillors are elected, for a four-year term, in each election.
The council is currently controlled by [Labour](/wiki/Labour_Party_\(UK\)
"Labour Party \(UK\)"). [West Yorkshire](/wiki/West_Yorkshire "West
Yorkshire") does not have a county council, so Leeds City Council is the
primary provider of local government services for the city. The district is in
the [Yorkshire and the Humber](/wiki/Yorkshire_and_the_Humber "Yorkshire and
the Humber") region of England.

Most of the district is an [unparished area](/wiki/Unparished_area "Unparished
area"). In the unparished area, there is no lower tier of government. Outside
the unparished area, there are 31 [civil parishes](/wiki/Civil_parish "Civil
parish"), represented by [parish councils](/wiki/Parish_councils_in_England
"Parish councils in England"). These are the lowest tier of local
government[80] and absorb some limited functions from Leeds City Council in
their areas.

The district is represented by eight [MPs](/wiki/Member_of_Parliament "Member
of Parliament"), for the constituencies of [Elmet and
Rothwell](/wiki/Elmet_and_Rothwell_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Elmet and
Rothwell \(UK Parliament constituency\)") ([Alec
Shelbrooke](/wiki/Alec_Shelbrooke "Alec Shelbrooke"), Conservative); [Leeds
Central](/wiki/Leeds_Central_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Leeds Central
\(UK Parliament constituency\)") ([Hilary Benn](/wiki/Hilary_Benn "Hilary
Benn"), Labour); [Leeds East](/wiki/Leeds_East_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\)
"Leeds East \(UK Parliament constituency\)") ([Richard
Burgon](/wiki/Richard_Burgon "Richard Burgon"), Labour); [Leeds North
East](/wiki/Leeds_North_East_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Leeds North East
\(UK Parliament constituency\)") ([Fabian Hamilton](/wiki/Fabian_Hamilton
"Fabian Hamilton"), Labour); [Leeds North
West](/wiki/Leeds_North_West_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Leeds North West
\(UK Parliament constituency\)") ([Alex Sobel](/wiki/Alex_Sobel "Alex Sobel"),
Labour); [Leeds West](/wiki/Leeds_West_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Leeds
West \(UK Parliament constituency\)") ([Rachel Reeves](/wiki/Rachel_Reeves
"Rachel Reeves"), Labour); [Morley and
Outwood](/wiki/Morley_and_Outwood_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Morley and
Outwood \(UK Parliament constituency\)") (constituency shared with [City of
Wakefield](/wiki/City_of_Wakefield "City of Wakefield")) ([Andrea
Jenkyns](/wiki/Andrea_Jenkyns "Andrea Jenkyns"), Conservative); and
[Pudsey](/wiki/Pudsey_\(UK_Parliament_constituency\) "Pudsey \(UK Parliament
constituency\)") ([Stuart Andrew](/wiki/Stuart_Andrew "Stuart Andrew"),
Conservative). Leeds is within the [Yorkshire and the
Humber](/wiki/Yorkshire_and_the_Humber_\(European_Parliament_constituency\)
"Yorkshire and the Humber \(European Parliament constituency\)") European
constituency, which as of May
2017[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit) is
represented by two [UKIP](/wiki/United_Kingdom_Independence_Party "United
Kingdom Independence Party"), two [Labour](/wiki/Labour_Party_\(UK\) "Labour
Party \(UK\)"), and two [Conservative](/wiki/Conservative_Party_\(UK\)
"Conservative Party \(UK\)") [MEPs](/wiki/Member_of_the_European_Parliament
"Member of the European Parliament").

In addition to other national governmental offices, the city is home to a
large [Department for Work and
Pensions](/wiki/Department_for_Work_and_Pensions "Department for Work and
Pensions") office building located in [Quarry Hill](/wiki/Quarry_Hill,_Leeds
"Quarry Hill, Leeds"), notable for its imposing design.

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Economy")]

Main article: [Economy of Leeds](/wiki/Economy_of_Leeds "Economy of Leeds")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Infirmary_Street%2C_Leeds_2012.jpg/220px-
Infirmary_Street%2C_Leeds_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Infirmary_Street,_Leeds_2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Infirmary_Street,_Leeds_2012.jpg "Enlarge")

Infirmary Street in the heart of Leeds' Financial District

Leeds has the most diverse economy of all the UK's main employment centres and
has seen the fastest rate of private sector jobs growth of any UK city and has
the highest ratio of public to private sector jobs of all the UK's Core
Cities. The city has the third largest jobs total by local authority area with
480,000 in employment and self-employment at the beginning of 2015.[81] 24.7%
were in public administration, education and health, 23.9% were in banking,
finance and insurance and 21.4% were in distribution, hotels and restaurants.
It is in the banking, finance and insurance sectors that Leeds differs most
from the financial structure of the region and the nation.[82] In 2011, the
financial and services industry in Leeds was worth £2.1 billion, the 5th
largest in the UK, behind London, Edinburgh, Manchester and Birmingham.[17]
Tertiary industries such as retail, [call centres](/wiki/Call_centre "Call
centre"), offices and media have contributed to a high rate of economic
growth. The city also hosts the only subsidiary office of the [Bank of
England](/wiki/Bank_of_England "Bank of England") in the UK. In 2012 GVA for
the city was recorded at £18.8 billion,[83] with the entire [Leeds City
Region](/wiki/Leeds_City_Region "Leeds City Region") generating a £56 billion
economy.[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Bridgewater_place%2CLeeds.JPG/220px-
Bridgewater_place%2CLeeds.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bridgewater_place,Leeds.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bridgewater_place,Leeds.JPG "Enlarge")

[Bridgewater Place](/wiki/Bridgewater_Place "Bridgewater Place")

It is the largest centre outside London for financial and business services.
Over the next ten years, the economy is forecast to grow by 25% with financial
and business services set to generate over half of GVA growth over that period
with Finance and business services accounting for 38% of total output. Other
key sectors include retail, leisure and the visitor economy, construction,
manufacturing and the creative and digital industries.[4]

Leeds has over 30 national and international banks, many of whose northern or
regional offices are based in the city. It is the headquarters for [First
Direct](/wiki/First_Direct "First Direct") and [Yorkshire
Bank](/wiki/Yorkshire_Bank "Yorkshire Bank"), and has large
[Barclays](/wiki/Barclays "Barclays"), [HSBC](/wiki/HSBC "HSBC"),
[Santander](/wiki/Santander_Group "Santander Group"), [Lloyds Banking
Group](/wiki/Lloyds_Banking_Group "Lloyds Banking Group") and [RBS
Group](/wiki/RBS_Group "RBS Group") operations.[84]

The city is also an important centre for equity, venture and risk finance.
Founded in Leeds, the venture capital provider, YFM Equity Partners, is now
the UK's largest provider of risk capital to small and medium-sized
enterprises.[84]

Other major companies based in the city include [William
Hill](/wiki/William_Hill_\(bookmaker\) "William Hill \(bookmaker\)"),
[International Personal Finance](/wiki/International_Personal_Finance
"International Personal Finance"), [ASDA](/wiki/ASDA "ASDA"), [Leeds Building
Society](/wiki/Leeds_Building_Society "Leeds Building Society") and [Northern
Foods](/wiki/Northern_Foods "Northern Foods"). [Capita
Group](/wiki/Capita_Group "Capita Group"), [KPMG](/wiki/KPMG "KPMG"), [Direct
Line](/wiki/Direct_Line "Direct Line"), [Aviva](/wiki/Aviva "Aviva"),
[Yorkshire Building Society](/wiki/Yorkshire_Building_Society "Yorkshire
Building Society"), [BT Group](/wiki/BT_Group "BT Group"), [Telefónica
Europe](/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica_Europe "Telefónica Europe") (otherwise known as
O2) and [TD Waterhouse](/wiki/TD_Waterhouse "TD Waterhouse") all also have a
considerable presence in the city.[84]

There are around 150 law firms operating in Leeds, employing over 6,700
people. According to The UK Legal 500, "Leeds has a sophisticated and highly
competitive legal market, second only to London."[85]

Specialist legal expertise to be found in Leeds includes corporate finance,
corporate restructuring and insolvency, global project financing, trade and
investment, commercial litigation, competition, construction, Private Finance
Initiatives and Public Private Partnerships, tax, derivatives, IT, employment,
pensions, intellectual property, sport and entertainment.[85]

The establishment of an Administrative Court in Leeds in April 2009 reinforced
Leeds' position as one of the UK's key legal centres. The court previously sat
only in London.[85]

Leeds is the UK's third largest manufacturing centre and 50% of the UK's
manufacturing base is within a two-hour drive of Leeds. With around 1,800
firms and 39,000 employees, Leeds manufacturing firms account for 8.8% of
total employment in the city. The largest sub-sectors are engineering,
printing and publishing, food and drink, chemicals and medical technology.[19]

There is also an established creative industry in the city, particularly in
the digital gaming sector. A number of large developers have studios in and
around the city, including [Activision](/wiki/Activision "Activision"),
developers of the mobile versions of the _[Call of Duty](/wiki/Call_of_Duty
"Call of Duty")_ series, and [Rockstar Leeds](/wiki/Rockstar_Leeds "Rockstar
Leeds"), developers of the _[Grand Theft Auto](/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto "Grand
Theft Auto")_ series. In 2009 Leeds was the first city outside London to host
the [Eurogamer Expo](/wiki/Eurogamer_Expo "Eurogamer Expo").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Park_Row_-
_Leeds.jpg/220px-Park_Row_-_Leeds.jpg)](/wiki/File:Park_Row_-_Leeds.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Park_Row_-_Leeds.jpg "Enlarge")

Park Row in Leeds' Central Business District

Office developments, also traditionally located in the inner area, have
expanded south of the River Aire and total 11,000,000 square feet (1,000,000
m2) of space.[86] In the period from 1999 to 2008 £2.5bn of property
development was undertaken in central Leeds; of which £711m has been offices,
£265m retail, £389m leisure and £794m housing. Manufacturing and distribution
uses accounts for £26m of new property development in the period. There are
130,100 jobs in the city centre, accounting for 31% of all jobs in the wider
district. In 2007, 47,500 jobs were in finance and business, 42,300 in public
services, and 19,500 in retail and distribution. 43% of finance sector jobs in
the district are contained in Leeds city centre and 44% of those employed in
the city centre live more than nine kilometres (5.6 miles) away.[86] Tourism
is important to the Leeds economy, in 2009 Leeds was the 8th most visited city
in England by UK visitors.[87] and the 13th most visited city by overseas
visitors.[88] Research by [VisitEngland](/wiki/VisitEngland "VisitEngland")
reported that the day visitor market to Leeds attracts 24.9 million people
each year, worth over £654 million to the local economy.[89]

In January 2011, Leeds was named as one of five "cities to watch" in a report
published by [Centre for Cities](/wiki/Centre_for_Cities "Centre for
Cities").[90] The report shows that the average resident in Leeds earns £471
per week,[91] seventeenth nationally and 30.9% of Leeds residents had NVQ4+
high level qualifications,[92] fifteenth nationally. Employment in Leeds was
68.8% in the period June 2012 to June 2013, which was lower than the national
average, whilst unemployment was higher than the national average at 9.6% over
the same time period.[93] It also shows that Leeds will be the least affected
major city by welfare cuts in 2014/2015, with welfare cuts of -£125 per capita
predicted, compared to -£192 in Liverpool and -£175 in Glasgow.[94] Leeds is
overall less deprived than other large UK cities and average income is above
regional averages.[69]

### Public sector[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Public sector")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/NHS_England_HQ.jpg/220px-
NHS_England_HQ.jpg)](/wiki/File:NHS_England_HQ.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NHS_England_HQ.jpg "Enlarge")

[NHS England](/wiki/NHS_England "NHS England") HQ.

In Leeds, 108,000 people work in the public sector – 24% of the workforce. The
largest employers are Leeds City Council, with 33,000 staff, and the Leeds
Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, with 14,000 staff.[95]

Leeds has become a hub of public-sector health bodies. The [Department of
Health](/wiki/Department_of_Health "Department of Health"), [NHS
England](/wiki/NHS_England "NHS England"), the [Care Quality
Commission](/wiki/Care_Quality_Commission "Care Quality Commission"), [NHS
Digital](/wiki/NHS_Digital "NHS Digital"), and [Public Health
England](/wiki/Public_Health_England "Public Health England") all have large
offices in Leeds. Europe's largest teaching hospital is also based in Leeds,
and is home to the Yorkshire Cancer Centre, the largest of its kind in
Europe.[96]

Key government departments and organisations in Leeds include the [Department
for Work and Pensions](/wiki/Department_for_Work_and_Pensions "Department for
Work and Pensions"), with over 3,000 staff, the Department of Health, with
over 800 staff, [HMRC](/wiki/HMRC "HMRC") with over 1,200 staff and the
[British Library](/wiki/British_Library "British Library") with 1,100
staff.[95]

Pinnacle%2C_Leeds_16.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pinnacle,_Leeds_16.jpg)

Opening_day%2C_Victoria_Gate%2C_Leeds_%2820th_October_2016%29_004.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opening_day,_Victoria_Gate,_Leeds_\(20th_October_2016\)_004.jpg)

"Enlarge")

[Victoria Gate](/wiki/Victoria_Gate "Victoria Gate") is Leeds' newest shopping

The extensive retail area of Leeds is identified as the principal regional
shopping centre for the whole of the Yorkshire and the Humber region with a
catchment of 5.5 million people offering a spend of £1.93 billion
annually.[97] There are a number of indoor shopping centres in the centre of
the city, including the [Merrion Centre](/wiki/Merrion_Centre,_Leeds "Merrion
Centre, Leeds"), [St John's Centre](/wiki/St_John%27s_Centre "St John's
Centre"), [The Core](/wiki/Headrow_Centre "Headrow Centre"), the [Victoria
Quarter](/wiki/Victoria_Quarter "Victoria Quarter"), [The
Light](/wiki/The_Light_\(Leeds\) "The Light \(Leeds\)"), the [Corn
Exchange](/wiki/Leeds_Corn_Exchange "Leeds Corn Exchange"), [Trinity
Leeds](/wiki/Trinity_Leeds "Trinity Leeds"), and [Victoria
Gate](/wiki/Victoria_Gate "Victoria Gate").[98] In total there are well over
1,000 retail stores, with a combined floorspace of 3,660,000 square feet
(340,000 m2).[86] in Leeds City Centre.

The city centre has a large [pedestrian zone](/wiki/Pedestrian_zone
"Pedestrian zone"). [Briggate](/wiki/Briggate "Briggate") is the main shopping
street where one can find many well-known British [High
street](/wiki/High_street "High street") stores, including [Marks &
Spencer](/wiki/Marks_%26_Spencer "Marks & Spencer"), [House of
Fraser](/wiki/House_of_Fraser "House of Fraser"), [Debenhams](/wiki/Debenhams
"Debenhams"), [Topshop](/wiki/Topshop "Topshop"), [Costa
Coffee](/wiki/Costa_Coffee "Costa Coffee") and [Harvey
Nichols](/wiki/Harvey_Nichols "Harvey Nichols"). Many companies have several
stores within Central Leeds and the wider city. The [Victoria
Quarter](/wiki/Victoria_Quarter "Victoria Quarter") is notable for its high-
end luxury retailers and impressive architecture. 70 stores such as [Louis
Vuitton](/wiki/Louis_Vuitton "Louis Vuitton"), [Vivienne
Westwood](/wiki/Vivienne_Westwood "Vivienne Westwood"), [Paul
Smith](/wiki/Paul_Smith_\(fashion_designer\) "Paul Smith \(fashion
designer\)"), [Diesel](/wiki/Diesel_\(brand\) "Diesel \(brand\)") and anchor
[Harvey Nichols](/wiki/Harvey_Nichols "Harvey Nichols") are contained within
two iron-wrought Victorian arcades, and a new arcade formed by arcading Queen
Victoria Street with the largest expanse of stained glass in Britain.[99][100]

In the Churwell area of Leeds is the [White Rose Shopping
Centre](/wiki/White_Rose_Shopping_Centre "White Rose Shopping Centre").
Opening in 1997, the centre has over 100 high street stores anchored by
Debenhams, Marks & Spencer, Primark and Sainsbury's. Some stores have their
only Leeds presence here and do not trade in Central Leeds, such as the Disney
Store and Build-A-Bear workshop. Although the centre is below the average
typical size for out of town shopping malls like the [Trafford
Centre](/wiki/Trafford_Centre "Trafford Centre") or
[Meadowhall](/wiki/Meadowhall_Centre "Meadowhall Centre") in nearby Yorkshire
city [Sheffield](/wiki/Sheffield "Sheffield"), it remains popular with
national and international chains. Of the 40,000 people who work in retailing
in Leeds 75% work in places which are not located in the city centre. There
are additional shopping centres located in the many villages that became part
of the county borough and in the towns that were incorporated in the City of
Leeds in 1974.[101]

On 21 March 2013, a large shopping and leisure complex called [Trinity
Leeds](/wiki/Trinity_Leeds "Trinity Leeds") opened in the city centre. The
modern and interactive retail space covers the old Burton Arcades and the
former [Leeds Shopping Plaza](/wiki/Leeds_Shopping_Plaza "Leeds Shopping
Plaza") with its main entrance from Briggate.[102]

On 20 October 2016, the newest shopping destination called [Victoria
Gate](/wiki/Victoria_Gate "Victoria Gate") opened its doors to the public. The
new shopping mall houses a flagship [John
Lewis](/wiki/John_Lewis_\(department_store\) "John Lewis \(department
store\)") store, the largest outside London. 75 per cent of the stores that
opened in Victoria Gate were new to Leeds with many of those stores being the
first outside of London.[103]

"Enlarge")

[The Old Post Office in Leeds City Square](/wiki/Leeds_City_Square "Leeds City

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Kirkstall_Abbey_at_sunset.jpg/220px-
Kirkstall_Abbey_at_sunset.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kirkstall_Abbey_at_sunset.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kirkstall_Abbey_at_sunset.jpg "Enlarge")

[Kirkstall Abbey](/wiki/Kirkstall_Abbey "Kirkstall Abbey"). Founded c.1152

Leeds displays a variety of natural and built landmarks. Natural landmarks
include such diverse sites as the gritstone outcrop of [Otley
Chevin](/wiki/The_Chevin "The Chevin") and the [Fairburn Ings RSPB
reserve](/wiki/Fairburn_Ings_RSPB_reserve "Fairburn Ings RSPB reserve"). The
city's parks at [Roundhay](/wiki/Roundhay_Park "Roundhay Park") and [Temple
Newsam](/wiki/Temple_Newsam "Temple Newsam") have long been owned and
maintained by the council for the benefit of ratepayers and among the open
spaces in the centre of Leeds are [Millennium
Square](/wiki/Millennium_Square_\(Leeds\) "Millennium Square \(Leeds\)"),
[City Square](/wiki/Leeds_City_Square "Leeds City Square"), [Park
Square](/wiki/Park_Square,_Leeds "Park Square, Leeds") and Victoria Gardens.
This last is the site of the central city [war memorial](/wiki/War_memorial
"War memorial"): there are 42 other war memorials in the suburbs, towns and
villages in the district.[104]

The built environment embraces edifices of civic pride like [Morley Town
Hall](/wiki/Morley_Town_Hall "Morley Town Hall") and the trio of buildings in
Leeds, [Leeds Town Hall](/wiki/Leeds_Town_Hall "Leeds Town Hall"), [Corn
Exchange](/wiki/Leeds_Corn_Exchange "Leeds Corn Exchange") and [Leeds City
Museum](/wiki/Leeds_City_Museum "Leeds City Museum") by the architect
[Cuthbert Brodrick](/wiki/Cuthbert_Brodrick "Cuthbert Brodrick"). The two
white buildings on the Leeds skyline are the Parkinson building of Leeds
University and the [Civic Hall](/wiki/Leeds_Civic_Hall "Leeds Civic Hall"),
with golden owls adorning the tops of the latter's twin spires.[105]

[Armley Mills](/wiki/Armley_Mills "Armley Mills"), [Tower
Works](/wiki/Tower_Works "Tower Works"), with its campanile-inspired towers,
and the Egyptian-style [Temple Works](/wiki/Temple_Works "Temple Works") hark
back to the city's industrial past, while the site and ruins of [Kirkstall
Abbey](/wiki/Kirkstall_Abbey "Kirkstall Abbey") display the beauty and
grandeur of [Cistercian](/wiki/Cistercian "Cistercian") architecture. Notable
churches are [Leeds Minster](/wiki/Leeds_Minster "Leeds Minster") (formerly
Leeds Parish Church), [St George's Church](/wiki/St_George%27s_Church,_Leeds
"St George's Church, Leeds") and [Leeds Cathedral](/wiki/Leeds_Cathedral
"Leeds Cathedral"), in the city centre, and the [Church of St John the
Baptist, Adel](/wiki/Church_of_St_John_the_Baptist,_Adel "Church of St John
the Baptist, Adel") and [Bardsey](/wiki/Bardsey,_West_Yorkshire "Bardsey, West
Yorkshire") Parish Church in quieter locations. Notable [non-
conformist](/wiki/Non-conformist "Non-conformist") chapels include the [Salem
Chapel](/wiki/Salem_Chapel,_Leeds "Salem Chapel, Leeds"), dating back to 1791
and notably the birthplace of Leeds United Football Club in 1919.[106][107]

Leeds is one of only a few UK cities outside of London to have a significant
number of [high-rise buildings](/wiki/High-rise_building "High-rise
building"), the 112-metre (367 ft) tower of [Bridgewater
Place](/wiki/Bridgewater_Place "Bridgewater Place"), also known as _The Dalek_
, is part of a major office and residential development and the region's
tallest building; it can be seen for miles around.[108] Bridgewater Place has
been the subject of debate as its erection in 2007 caused significant [Wind
Tunnel](/wiki/Wind_Tunnel "Wind Tunnel") effects, channeling strong wind
currents across Victoria Road. There have been numerous injuries attributed to
the inadequate architecture of this building[109] and Water Lane is frequently
closed when high winds are expected. [Leeds City
Council](/wiki/Leeds_City_Council "Leeds City Council") are undertaking
construction work in an attempt to deflect the wind from street level and the
building owners of Bridgewater Place agreed to pay to cover the public money
being spent.[110] Among other Skyscrapers the 37-storey [Sky
Plaza](/wiki/Sky_Plaza "Sky Plaza") to the north of the city centre stands on
higher ground so that its 106 metres (348 ft) is higher than Bridgewater
Place.

[Elland Road](/wiki/Elland_Road "Elland Road") (football) and [Headingley
Stadium](/wiki/Headingley_Stadium "Headingley Stadium") (cricket and rugby)
are well known to sports enthusiasts and the [White Rose
Centre](/wiki/White_Rose_Centre "White Rose Centre") is a well-known retail
outlet. Headingley Carnegie Stadium is also home to Leeds Rhinos rugby team.

[A65](/wiki/A65_road "A65 road") and [A660](/wiki/A660_road "A660 road")
roads, and is also situated on the [A58](/wiki/A58_road "A58 road") and
[A61](/wiki/A61_road "A61 road"). The [M1](/wiki/M1_motorway "M1 motorway")
and [M62](/wiki/M62_motorway "M62 motorway") intersect to its south and the
[A1(M)](/wiki/A1\(M\)_motorway_\(Great_Britain\) "A1\(M\) motorway \(Great
Britain\)") passes to the east. Leeds is one of the principal hubs of the
northern motorway network. Additionally, there is an urban motorway network;
the radial [M621](/wiki/M621_motorway "M621 motorway") takes traffic into
central Leeds from the M62 and M1. There is an [Inner Ring
Road](/wiki/Leeds_Inner_Ring_Road "Leeds Inner Ring Road") with part motorway
status and an [Outer Ring Road](/wiki/Leeds_Outer_Ring_Road "Leeds Outer Ring
Road"). Part of the city centre[111] is pedestrianised, and is encircled by
the clockwise-only [Loop Road](/wiki/Leeds_City_Centre_Loop_Road "Leeds City
Centre Loop Road").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Leeds_city_railway_station.jpg/220px-
Leeds_city_railway_station.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds_city_railway_station.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_city_railway_station.jpg "Enlarge")

[Leeds railway station](/wiki/Leeds_railway_station "Leeds railway station")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/LBIA_terminal_1.jpg/220px-
LBIA_terminal_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:LBIA_terminal_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LBIA_terminal_1.jpg "Enlarge")

[Leeds Bradford International
Airport](/wiki/Leeds_Bradford_International_Airport "Leeds Bradford
International Airport")

Leeds has been identified as one of the most car-dependent cities in the
UK.[112] In one 2012 study of 31 European cities, Leeds-Bradford was rated as
the seventh most grid-locked.[113][114] Drivers spend an average of 80 hours
in congestion.[115] Measurements taken on some main roads in Leeds have
revealed pollution levels over twice the legal limits.[116] The main reason
for these problems is the fact that unlike other cities in the UK similar in
size to Leeds, such as [Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester") and
[Sheffield](/wiki/Sheffield "Sheffield"), Leeds does not have a rapid
transport system (such as the [Manchester
Metrolink](/wiki/Manchester_Metrolink "Manchester Metrolink") or [Sheffield
Supertram](/wiki/Sheffield_Supertram "Sheffield Supertram")). Therefore
commuters tend to either drive or use buses, which can be delayed when the
roads are congested. There were plans for a [Leeds
Supertram](/wiki/Leeds_Supertram "Leeds Supertram") in the 1990s, and £500
million in funding was to be provided, however due to spiraling costs the
plans were cancelled by the Transport Minister [Alistair
Darling](/wiki/Alistair_Darling "Alistair Darling") in 2005, even though £40
million had already been spent on the project. Hopes were renewed with the
proposal for a £250 million [New Generation
Transport](/wiki/New_Generation_Transport "New Generation Transport")
Trolleybus service in 2007, however after a long wait and millions of pounds
spent on inquiries, the plans were cancelled in May 2016 citing little value
for money.[117]

Public transport in the Leeds area is coordinated and developed by [West
Yorkshire Metro](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Metro "West Yorkshire Metro"),[118] with
service information provided by Leeds City Council[119] and West Yorkshire
Metro. The primary means of public transport in Leeds are the bus services.
The main provider is [First Leeds](/wiki/First_Leeds "First Leeds") and
[Arriva Yorkshire](/wiki/Arriva_Yorkshire "Arriva Yorkshire") serves routes to
the south of the city. Leeds City bus station is at Dyer Street and is used by
bus services to towns and cities in Yorkshire, plus a small number of local
services. Adjacent to it is the coach station for [National
Express](/wiki/National_Express_Coaches "National Express Coaches") coach
services. Buses out of the city are mainly provided by [First
Leeds](/wiki/First_Leeds "First Leeds") and [Arriva
Yorkshire](/wiki/Arriva_Yorkshire "Arriva Yorkshire"). [Harrogate Bus
Company](/wiki/Harrogate_Bus_Company "Harrogate Bus Company") provides a
service to [Harrogate](/wiki/Harrogate "Harrogate") and [Ripon](/wiki/Ripon
"Ripon"). [Keighley Bus Company](/wiki/Keighley_Bus_Company "Keighley Bus
Company") provides a service to [Shipley](/wiki/Shipley,_West_Yorkshire
"Shipley, West Yorkshire"), [Bingley](/wiki/Bingley "Bingley") and
[Keighley](/wiki/Keighley "Keighley"). The [Yorkshire
Coastliner](/wiki/Yorkshire_Coastliner "Yorkshire Coastliner") service runs
from Leeds to [Bridlington](/wiki/Bridlington "Bridlington"),
[Filey](/wiki/Filey "Filey"), [Scarborough](/wiki/Scarborough,_North_Yorkshire
"Scarborough, North Yorkshire") and [Whitby](/wiki/Whitby "Whitby") via
[York](/wiki/York "York") and [Malton](/wiki/Malton,_North_Yorkshire "Malton,
North Yorkshire"). [Stagecoach](/wiki/Stagecoach_in_Hull "Stagecoach in Hull")
provides a service to [Hull](/wiki/Kingston_upon_Hull "Kingston upon Hull")
via [Goole](/wiki/Goole "Goole").

From [Leeds railway station](/wiki/Leeds_railway_station "Leeds railway
station") at New Station Street, [West Yorkshire
Metro](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Metro "West Yorkshire Metro") trains operated by
[Northern](/wiki/Northern_\(train_operating_company\) "Northern \(train
operating company\)") run to Leeds' suburbs and onwards to all parts of Leeds
City Region. The station is one of the busiest in England outside London, with
over 900 trains and 50,000 passengers passing through every day.[120] It
provides national and international connections as well as services to local
and regional destinations. The station itself has 17 platforms, making it the
largest in England outside London.[121]

[Leeds Bradford International
Airport](/wiki/Leeds_Bradford_International_Airport "Leeds Bradford
International Airport") is located in [Yeadon](/wiki/Yeadon,_West_Yorkshire
"Yeadon, West Yorkshire"), about 10 miles (16 km) to the north-west of the
city centre, and has both charter and scheduled flights to destinations within
Europe plus Egypt, Tunisia, Pakistan, Turkey and the USA. There is a direct
rail service from Leeds to [Manchester Airport](/wiki/Manchester_Airport
"Manchester Airport"); however, there isn't one to the nearby Leeds Bradford
Airport. [Humberside Airport](/wiki/Humberside_Airport "Humberside Airport")
is 70 miles (113 km) east of Leeds.

The city and metropolitan borough of Leeds is served by 16 railway stations
and there are plans to open several more within the next 20 years.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Walking[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Walking")]

The [Leeds Country Way](/wiki/Leeds_Country_Way "Leeds Country Way") is a
waymarked circular walk of 62 miles (100 km) through the rural outskirts of
the city, never more than 7 miles (11 km) from [City
Square](/wiki/Leeds_City_Square "Leeds City Square"). The [Meanwood Valley
Trail](/wiki/Meanwood_Valley_Trail "Meanwood Valley Trail") leads from
[Woodhouse Moor](/wiki/Woodhouse_Moor "Woodhouse Moor") along [Meanwood
Beck](/wiki/Meanwood_Beck "Meanwood Beck") to [Golden Acre
Park](/wiki/Golden_Acre_Park "Golden Acre Park"). The Leeds extension of the
[Dales Way](/wiki/Dales_Way "Dales Way") follows the Meanwood Valley Trail
before it branches off to head towards [Ilkley](/wiki/Ilkley "Ilkley") and
[Windermere](/wiki/Windermere "Windermere"). Leeds is on the northern section
of the [Trans Pennine Trail](/wiki/Trans_Pennine_Trail "Trans Pennine Trail")
for walkers and cyclists, and the towpath of the [Leeds and Liverpool
Canal](/wiki/Leeds_and_Liverpool_Canal "Leeds and Liverpool Canal") is another
popular walking and cycling route. [The White Rose
Way](/wiki/The_White_Rose_Way "The White Rose Way") walking trail to
[Scarborough](/wiki/Scarborough,_North_Yorkshire "Scarborough, North
Yorkshire") begins at City Square. In addition, there are many parks and
public footpaths in both the urban and rural parts of Leeds, and the
[Ramblers' Association](/wiki/Ramblers%27_Association "Ramblers'
Association"), [YHA](/wiki/Youth_Hostels_Association_\(England_%26_Wales\)
"Youth Hostels Association \(England & Wales\)") and other walking
organisations offer sociable walks. The Ramblers' Association publish various
booklets of walks in and around Leeds.[122]

### Parks and open
spaces[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section:
Parks and open spaces")]

Leeds has many large parks and open spaces. [Roundhay
Park](/wiki/Roundhay_Park "Roundhay Park") is the largest park in the city,
and is one of the largest city parks in Europe. The park has more than 700
acres (2.8 km2)[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] of parkland, lakes, woodland and gardens which
are all owned by Leeds City Council. Other parks in the city include:
[Middleton Park](/wiki/Middleton_Park "Middleton Park"), [Temple
Newsam](/wiki/Temple_Newsam "Temple Newsam"), [Woodhouse
Moor](/wiki/Woodhouse_Moor "Woodhouse Moor"), Meanwood Park, Beckett Park,
Bramley Fall Park, Horforth Hall Park, Potternewton Park, [Golden Acre
Park](/wiki/Golden_Acre_Park "Golden Acre Park"), East End Park, Cross Flatts
Park, and Western Flatts Park. There are many more smaller parks and open
spaces scattered around the city, which makes Leeds one of the Greenest cities
in the United Kingdom.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Education")]

### Schools[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Schools")]

Main article: [List of schools in Leeds](/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Leeds "List
of schools in Leeds")

At the time of the 2001 census Leeds had a population of 183,000 young people
aged 0–19 of whom 110,000 were attending local authority schools.[123] In 2008
Education Leeds, a non-profit company owned by Leeds City Council, provided
for 220 primary schools, 39 secondary schools and 6 special inclusive learning
centres.[124] Under the government [Building Schools for the
Future](/wiki/Building_Schools_for_the_Future "Building Schools for the
Future") initiative, Leeds secured £260m, to transform 13 secondary schools
into high achieving, e-confident, inclusive schools. The first three of these
schools at [Allerton High School](/wiki/Allerton_High_School "Allerton High
School"), [Pudsey Grangefield School](/wiki/Pudsey_Grangefield_School "Pudsey
Grangefield School") and [Rodillian School](/wiki/Rodillian_School "Rodillian
School"), were opened in September 2008.[125] The demand for primary school
places in Leeds has recently hit a 15-year peak, with an estimated 10,500 new
starters this year.[126] The city's oldest and largest private school is [The
Grammar School at Leeds](/wiki/The_Grammar_School_at_Leeds "The Grammar School
at Leeds"), which was legally re-created in 2005 following the merger of
[Leeds Grammar School](/wiki/Leeds_Grammar_School "Leeds Grammar School"),
established 1552, and [Leeds Girls' High
School](/wiki/Leeds_Girls%27_High_School "Leeds Girls' High School"),
established 1857. Other independent schools in Leeds include faith schools
serving the Jewish[127] and Muslim[128] communities.

Leeds was one of a number of local authorities to try the [three-tier
system](/wiki/Three-tier_education "Three-tier education") with first, middle
and secondary schools. It reverted to the two-tier system in 1992.

Broadcasting_Tower%2C_Leeds%2C_West_Yorkshire.jpg)](/wiki/File:Broadcasting_Tower,_Leeds,_West_Yorkshire.jpg)

Broadcasting Tower at the [Leeds Beckett
