[Further education](/wiki/Further_education "Further education") in Leeds is
provided by [Leeds City College](/wiki/Leeds_City_College "Leeds City
College") (formed by a merger in 2009 and having over 60,000 students), [Leeds
College of Building](/wiki/Leeds_College_of_Building "Leeds College of
Building"), [Notre Dame Catholic Sixth Form
College](/wiki/Notre_Dame_Catholic_Sixth_Form_College "Notre Dame Catholic
Sixth Form College") and [Elliott Hudson College](/wiki/Elliott_Hudson_College
"Elliott Hudson College"). The city has five universities: the [University of
Leeds](/wiki/University_of_Leeds "University of Leeds") – which received its
charter in 1904 having developed from the Yorkshire College which was founded
in 1874 and the Leeds School of Medicine of 1831; [Leeds Beckett
University](/wiki/Leeds_Beckett_University "Leeds Beckett University")
(formerly Leeds Polytechnic) which became a university in 1992 but can trace
its roots to the [Mechanics' Institute](/wiki/Mechanics%27_Institute
"Mechanics' Institute") of 1824; [Leeds Trinity
University](/wiki/Leeds_Trinity_University "Leeds Trinity University") which
began in 1966 as two teacher training colleges which merged in 1980 to form
Trinity and All Saints College and became a university in 2012; the
[University of Law](/wiki/University_of_Law "University of Law") (formerly the
College of Law) which became a university in 2012 and moved to its current
Leeds centre campus from [York](/wiki/York "York") in 2014; and [Leeds Arts
University](/wiki/Leeds_Arts_University "Leeds Arts University"), which was
founded in 1846 as the Leeds School of Art, and became a university in 2017.

The University of Leeds has about 31,000 students, of which 21,500 are full-
time or sandwich undergraduate degree students,[129] Leeds Beckett University
has 25,805[130] students of which 12,000 are full-time or sandwich
undergraduate degree students and 2,100 full-time or sandwich HND
students.[131] Leeds Trinity University has just under 3,000 students,[132]
Other higher education establishments are: [Leeds College of
Music](/wiki/Leeds_College_of_Music "Leeds College of Music") and [Northern
School of Contemporary Dance](/wiki/Northern_School_of_Contemporary_Dance
"Northern School of Contemporary Dance"). The city was voted the Best UK
University Destination by a survey in _[The Independent](/wiki/The_Independent
"The Independent")_ newspaper.[133]

## Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Culture")]

See also: [Culture of Leeds](/wiki/Culture_of_Leeds "Culture of Leeds")

### Art[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section:
Art")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Leeds._Henry_Moore_town_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_353135.jpg/220px-Leeds._Henry_Moore_town_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_353135.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds._Henry_Moore_town_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_353135.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds._Henry_Moore_town_-_geograph.org.uk_-_353135.jpg
"Enlarge")

Henry Moore Statue outside [Leeds Art Gallery](/wiki/Leeds_Art_Gallery "Leeds
Art Gallery")

Although the city's municipal art gallery did not open until 1888, the history
of art practise and collecting has a long history in Leeds. [J. M. W.
Turner](/wiki/J._M._W._Turner "J. M. W. Turner") painted numerous scenes in
and around the city,[134] and the city was home to one of Britain's largest
collections of Pre-Raphaelite Art, owned by Thomas Plint, during the
nineteenth century.[135] There was also an early history of holding larg-scale
public exhibitions in the city, most notably the series of 'Polytechnic
Exhibitions' held regularly from 1839.[136]

Leeds produced many notable artists and sculptors, including [Kenneth
Armitage](/wiki/Kenneth_Armitage "Kenneth Armitage"), [John Atkinson
Grimshaw](/wiki/John_Atkinson_Grimshaw "John Atkinson Grimshaw"), [Jacob
Kramer](/wiki/Jacob_Kramer "Jacob Kramer"), [Barbara
Hepworth](/wiki/Barbara_Hepworth "Barbara Hepworth"), [Henry
Moore](/wiki/Henry_Moore "Henry Moore") and [Edward
Wadsworth](/wiki/Edward_Wadsworth "Edward Wadsworth"), and was the centre for
a particularly radical strain of British art. Before the First World War Leeds
was the home of an unusual modernist arts organisation, called the [Leeds Arts
Club](/wiki/Leeds_Arts_Club "Leeds Arts Club"), founded by [Alfred
Orage](/wiki/Alfred_Orage "Alfred Orage"), which lasted from 1903 to 1923.
Notable members included [Jacob Kramer](/wiki/Jacob_Kramer "Jacob Kramer"),
[Herbert Read](/wiki/Herbert_Read "Herbert Read"), [Frank
Rutter](/wiki/Frank_Rutter "Frank Rutter") and [Michael
Sadler](/wiki/Michael_Sadler_\(educationist\) "Michael Sadler
\(educationist\)"). As well as advocating a radical political agenda,
supporting the [Suffragettes](/wiki/Suffragettes "Suffragettes"), the
[Independent Labour Party](/wiki/Independent_Labour_Party "Independent Labour
Party") and the [Fabian Society](/wiki/Fabian_Society "Fabian Society"), and
promoting the philosophy of [Friedrich Nietzsche](/wiki/Friedrich_Nietzsche
"Friedrich Nietzsche"), the Leeds Arts Club was almost unique in Britain as
being an exponent of [German Expressionist](/wiki/German_Expressionist "German
Expressionist") ideas about art and culture. As a result, it staged very early
British exhibitions of work by European expressionist artists, such as
[Wassily Kandinsky](/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky "Wassily Kandinsky"), showing
their work in the city as early as 1913,[137] and produced its own English
Expressionist artists, including Jacob Kramer and Bruce Turner.[138]

In the 1920s Leeds College of Art was the starting point for the careers of
the sculptors [Barbara Hepworth](/wiki/Barbara_Hepworth "Barbara Hepworth")
and [Henry Moore](/wiki/Henry_Moore "Henry Moore"), and in the 1950s, and
1960s it was one of the leading centres for radical art education in Britain
under the guidance of artists such as [Harry Thubron](/wiki/Harry_Thubron
"Harry Thubron") and [Tom Hudson](/wiki/Thomas_Hudson_\(painter\) "Thomas
Hudson \(painter\)"), and the art historian [Norbert
Lynton](/wiki/Norbert_Lynton "Norbert Lynton"). Their attempts to redefine
what art education should mean in the post-Second World War period led the
artist [Patrick Heron](/wiki/Patrick_Heron "Patrick Heron") to claim in 1971
in _The Guardian_ newspaper that 'Leeds is the most influential art school in
Europe since the [Bauhaus](/wiki/Bauhaus "Bauhaus")'.[139] This willingness to
push at the boundaries of acceptable public behaviour from artists was also
evident in 1966 when Leeds College of Art staged an exhibition of paintings by
the Cypriot artist [Stass Paraskos](/wiki/Stass_Paraskos "Stass Paraskos"),
who taught at the College, which was raided by the police after allegations of
obscenity.[140]

This radicalism continued into the 1970s when the higher education component
of Leeds College of Art was split from the college to form the nucleus of the
new multidisciplinary [Leeds Polytechnic](/wiki/Leeds_Polytechnic "Leeds
Polytechnic"), now called [Leeds Beckett
University](/wiki/Leeds_Beckett_University "Leeds Beckett University").
Performance art had been taught earlier at Leeds College of Art, notably by
the [Fluxus](/wiki/Fluxus "Fluxus") artist [Robin Page](/wiki/Robin_Page
"Robin Page") during his time as a tutor there in the mid-1960s, but in 1977 a
performance art work hit the national news headlines when the students Pete
Parkin and Derek Wain used an air pistol to shoot a line up of live
[budgerigars](/wiki/Budgerigars "Budgerigars") in front of an audience at
Leeds Polytechnic.[141]

The [University of Leeds](/wiki/University_of_Leeds "University of Leeds") was
the _alma mater_ of [Herbert Read](/wiki/Herbert_Read "Herbert Read"), one of
the leading international theorists of modern art from the mid-twentieth
century,[142] and also the teaching base for the [Marxist](/wiki/Marxist
"Marxist") art historian [Arnold Hauser](/wiki/Arnold_Hauser "Arnold Hauser")
from 1951 to 1985.[143] Partly due to Herbert Read's connection with the
University, from 1950 to 1970 the University was the host of one of the first
[artist in residence](/wiki/Artist_in_residence "Artist in residence") schemes
in Britain, using funding from the then owner of [Lund
Humphries](/wiki/Lund_Humphries "Lund Humphries") books, Peter Gregory. The
Gregory Fellowships, as the residencies were known, were given to painters and
sculptors for up to two years to allow them to develop their own work and
influence the University in any way they saw fit. Amongst those holding the
fellowships were [Kenneth Armitage](/wiki/Kenneth_Armitage "Kenneth
Armitage"), [Reg Butler](/wiki/Reg_Butler "Reg Butler"), [Dennis
Creffield](/wiki/Dennis_Creffield "Dennis Creffield") and [Terry
Frost](/wiki/Terry_Frost "Terry Frost") and others. Parallel Gregory
Fellowships also existed in music and poetry at the University.[144]

Leeds was also a centre for radical feminist art, with one of the first
galleries in Britain dedicated to showing the work of women photographers, the
Pavilion Gallery, opening in the city in 1983, and the [University of
Leeds](/wiki/University_of_Leeds "University of Leeds") School of Fine Art
being a well-known centre for the development of feminist art history, under
[Griselda Pollock](/wiki/Griselda_Pollock "Griselda Pollock"), during the
1980s and 1990s. Possibly as a result of the strength of feminist art in
Leeds, in November 1984 an exhibition of ceramics by students and staff at
Leeds Polytechnic was attacked by a group of feminist activists who destroyed
eight sculptures on display which they deemed to be degrading to women.[145]
The University of Leeds's School of Fine Art also specialised in [Art and
Language](/wiki/Art_and_Language "Art and Language") conceptual art practice,
under [Terry Atkinson](/wiki/Terry_Atkinson "Terry Atkinson"), again in the
1980s and 1990s.[146]

A major sculpture research centre and gallery, the [Henry Moore
Institute](/wiki/Henry_Moore_Institute "Henry Moore Institute"), is located
alongside [Leeds Art Gallery](/wiki/Leeds_Art_Gallery "Leeds Art Gallery") in
the city centre, and in 2013 a new contemporary art centre, called [The
Tetley](/wiki/The_Tetley_\(Leeds\) "The Tetley \(Leeds\)"), opened on the site
of the former Tetley Brewery to the south of the city centre.

In March 2017, [The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times") voted Leeds as the
number one cultural place to live in Britain. This was ahead of London,
[Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham"), [St Ives](/wiki/St_Ives,_Cornwall
"St Ives, Cornwall"), [Stratford-upon-Avon](/wiki/Stratford-upon-Avon
"Stratford-upon-Avon") and [Cheltenham](/wiki/Cheltenham "Cheltenham"). The
citation notes that Leeds has [Opera North](/wiki/Opera_North "Opera North"),
the [Northern Ballet](/wiki/Northern_Ballet "Northern Ballet"), the [West
Yorkshire Playhouse](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Playhouse "West Yorkshire
Playhouse") amongst may other attractions that ranked it at number one.[147]

### Carnivals and
festivals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Carnivals and festivals")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Leeds_West_Indian_Carnival.jpg/220px-
Leeds_West_Indian_Carnival.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds_West_Indian_Carnival.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_West_Indian_Carnival.jpg "Enlarge")

[Leeds Carnival](/wiki/Leeds_Carnival "Leeds Carnival")

[Leeds Carnival](/wiki/Leeds_Carnival "Leeds Carnival") is Western Europe's
oldest West Indian Carnival, and the UK's third largest after the Notting Hill
and Nottingham Carnival.[148][149] It attracts around 100,000 people over 2
days to the streets of Chapeltown and Harehills. There is a large procession
that finishes at Potternewton Park, where there are stalls, entertainment and
refreshments. The [Leeds Festival](/wiki/Reading_and_Leeds_Festivals "Reading
and Leeds Festivals"), featuring some of the biggest names in rock and indie
music, takes place every year in [Bramham Park](/wiki/Bramham_Park "Bramham
Park"). The Leeds Asian Festival, formerly the Leeds
[Mela](/wiki/Mela_Festival "Mela Festival"), is held in Roundhay Park.[150]
The [Otley](/wiki/Otley "Otley") Folk Festival (patron: [Nic
Jones](/wiki/Nic_Jones "Nic Jones")),[151] Walking Festival,[152]
Carnival[153] and Victorian Christmas Fayre[154] are annual events. [Light
Night](/wiki/Light_Night "Light Night") Leeds takes place each October,[155]
and many venues in the city are open to the public for [Heritage Open
Days](/wiki/Heritage_Open_Days "Heritage Open Days") in September.[156] The
[Leeds International Pianoforte
Competition](/wiki/Leeds_International_Pianoforte_Competition "Leeds
International Pianoforte Competition"), established in 1963 by [Fanny
Waterman](/wiki/Fanny_Waterman "Fanny Waterman") and [Marion
Stein](/wiki/Marion_Stein "Marion Stein"), has been held in the city every
three years since 1963 and has launched the careers of many major concert
pianists. The Leeds International Concert Season, which includes orchestral
and choral concerts in [Leeds Town Hall](/wiki/Leeds_Town_Hall "Leeds Town
Hall") and other events, is the largest local authority music programme in the
UK.[157]

The [Leeds International Film
Festival](/wiki/Leeds_International_Film_Festival "Leeds International Film
Festival") is the largest film festival in England outside London[158] and
shows films from around the world. It incorporates the highly successful
_Leeds Young People 's Film Festival_, which features exciting and innovative
films made both for and by children and young people.[159]
[Garforth](/wiki/Garforth "Garforth") is host to the fortnight long festival
The [Garforth Arts Festival](/wiki/Garforth_Arts_Festival "Garforth Arts
Festival") which has been an annual event since 2005. The [Chapel
Allerton](/wiki/Chapel_Allerton "Chapel Allerton") Arts Festival is a week-
long music and arts event starting in 1998 and held the week after August Bank
Holiday each year.[160] The [Leeds Festival
Fringe](/wiki/Leeds_Festival_Fringe "Leeds Festival Fringe") is a week long-
music festival created in 2010 to showcase local talent in the week prior to
[Leeds Festival](/wiki/Leeds_and_Reading_festivals "Leeds and Reading
festivals").

### Cinema[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Cinema")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Louis_Le_Prince.jpg/220px-
Louis_Le_Prince.jpg)](/wiki/File:Louis_Le_Prince.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Louis_Le_Prince.jpg "Enlarge")

[Louis Le Prince](/wiki/Louis_Le_Prince "Louis Le Prince")

In October 1888 [Louis Le Prince](/wiki/Louis_Le_Prince "Louis Le Prince")
filmed moving picture sequences _[Roundhay Garden
Scene](/wiki/Roundhay_Garden_Scene "Roundhay Garden Scene")_ and a _[Leeds
Bridge](/wiki/Leeds_Bridge "Leeds Bridge")_ street scene using his single-lens
camera and [Eastman](/wiki/Eastman_Kodak "Eastman Kodak")'s paper film.[161]
These were several years before the work of competing inventors such as
[Auguste and Louis Lumière](/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re "Auguste and
Louis Lumière") and [Thomas Edison](/wiki/Thomas_Edison "Thomas Edison").
Today, [Leeds International Film
Festival](/wiki/Leeds_International_Film_Festival "Leeds International Film
Festival")'s International Short Film Competition is named after Louis Le
Prince.[162] The 2015 documentary film _[The First Film](/wiki/The_First_Film
"The First Film")_ , which first aired at the [Edinburgh International Film
Festival](/wiki/Edinburgh_International_Film_Festival "Edinburgh International
Film Festival"), documents Le Prince's pioneering status.[163]

[Wordsworth Donisthorpe](/wiki/Wordsworth_Donisthorpe "Wordsworth
Donisthorpe") who was also from Leeds, filmed the second oldest surviving
film. It is not known if he and Louis Le Prince ever met but they both had a
strong connection to the [Leeds Philosophical and Literary
Society](/wiki/Leeds_Philosophical_and_Literary_Society "Leeds Philosophical
and Literary Society"). Donisthorpe's patent for a camera to capture the
moving image pre dated Le Prince's by twelve years.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Leeds has a rich film exhibition culture. In addition to the [Leeds
International Film Festival](/wiki/Leeds_International_Film_Festival "Leeds
International Film Festival") and Leeds Young Film Festival, the city hosts
numerous independent cinemas and pop-up venues for film screenings.[164] [The
Cottage Road Cinema](/wiki/The_Cottage_Road_Cinema "The Cottage Road Cinema")
and [Hyde Park Picture House](/wiki/Hyde_Park_Picture_House,_Leeds "Hyde Park
Picture House, Leeds") have continuously been showing films since 1912 and
1914 respectively, which ranks them among the oldest still running cinemas in
the UK.[165]

[BBC Yorkshire](/wiki/BBC_Yorkshire "BBC Yorkshire") studios

[Yorkshire Post Newspapers Ltd](/wiki/Yorkshire_Post_Newspapers_Ltd "Yorkshire
Post Newspapers Ltd"), owned by [Johnston Press plc](/wiki/Johnston_Press_plc
"Johnston Press plc"), is based in the city, and produces a daily morning
broadsheet, the _[Yorkshire Post](/wiki/Yorkshire_Post "Yorkshire Post")_ ,
and an evening paper, the _[Yorkshire Evening
Post](/wiki/Yorkshire_Evening_Post "Yorkshire Evening Post")_ (YEP). The YEP
has a website which includes a series of community pages which focus on
specific areas of the city.[166] The _[Wetherby News](/wiki/Wetherby_News
"Wetherby News")_ covers mainly areas within the north eastern sector of the
district, and the _[Wharfedale& Airedale
Observer](/wiki/Wharfedale_%26_Airedale_Observer "Wharfedale & Airedale
Observer")_, published in [Ilkley](/wiki/Ilkley "Ilkley"), covers the north
west, both appearing weekly. The two largest universities both have [student
newspapers](/wiki/Student_newspaper "Student newspaper"), the weekly _[Leeds
Student](/wiki/Leeds_Student "Leeds Student")_ from the University of Leeds
and the monthly _[The Met](/wiki/The_Met_\(newspaper\) "The Met
\(newspaper\)")_ from Leeds Beckett University. _[The Leeds
Guide](/wiki/The_Leeds_Guide "The Leeds Guide")_ was a fortnightly listings
magazine, which was established in 1997 and ceased publication in 2012. Free
publications include the _Leeds Weekly News_ , produced by Yorkshire Post
Newspapers in four geographic versions and distributed to households in the
main urban area of the city,[167] and the regional version of
_[Metro](/wiki/Metro_\(Associated_Metro_Limited\) "Metro \(Associated Metro
Limited\)")_ which is distributed on buses and at railway stations.

Regional television and radio stations have bases in the city; [BBC
Television](/wiki/BBC "BBC") and [ITV](/wiki/ITV_Network "ITV Network") both
have regional studios and broadcasting centres in Leeds. [ITV
Yorkshire](/wiki/ITV_Yorkshire "ITV Yorkshire"), formerly [Yorkshire
Television](/wiki/Yorkshire_Television "Yorkshire Television"), broadcasts
from [the Leeds Studios](/wiki/The_Leeds_Studios "The Leeds Studios") on
Kirkstall Road. There are a number of independent film production companies,
including the not-for-profit cooperative Leeds Animation Workshop, founded in
1978; community video producers Vera Media and several small commercial
production companies. [BBC Radio Leeds](/wiki/BBC_Radio_Leeds "BBC Radio
Leeds"), [Radio Aire](/wiki/Radio_Aire "Radio Aire"), [Magic
828](/wiki/Magic_828 "Magic 828"), [Capital Yorkshire](/wiki/Capital_Yorkshire
"Capital Yorkshire"), [Real Radio](/wiki/Real_Radio_\(Yorkshire\) "Real Radio
\(Yorkshire\)") and [Yorkshire Radio](/wiki/Yorkshire_Radio "Yorkshire Radio")
broadcast from the city. [LSRfm.com](/wiki/LSRfm.com "LSRfm.com"), is based in
[Leeds University Union](/wiki/Leeds_University_Union "Leeds University
Union"), and regularly hosts outside broadcasts around the city. Many
communities within Leeds now have their own local radio stations, such as
[East Leeds FM](/wiki/East_Leeds_FM "East Leeds FM") and [Tempo
FM](/wiki/Tempo_FM "Tempo FM") for [Wetherby](/wiki/Wetherby "Wetherby") and
the surrounding areas.

[Made in Leeds](/wiki/Made_in_Leeds "Made in Leeds") is a local television
station which launched across the city in 2014.[168] A privately owned
television station: Leeds Television is run by volunteers and supported by
professionals in the media industry.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Leeds Museum Discovery Centre

A new [Leeds City Museum](/wiki/Leeds_City_Museum "Leeds City Museum") opened
in 2008[169] in [Millennium Square](/wiki/Millennium_Square_\(Leeds\)
"Millennium Square \(Leeds\)"). [Abbey House Museum](/wiki/Abbey_House_Museum
"Abbey House Museum") is housed in the former gatehouse of [Kirkstall
Abbey](/wiki/Kirkstall_Abbey "Kirkstall Abbey"), and includes walk-through
Victorian streets and galleries describing the history of the abbey,
childhood, and Victorian Leeds. [Armley Mills Industrial
Museum](/wiki/Armley_Mills_Industrial_Museum "Armley Mills Industrial Museum")
is housed in what was once the world's largest woollen mill,[170] and includes
industrial machinery and railway locomotives. This museum also shows the first
known moving pictures in the world which were taken in the city, by [Louis Le
Prince](/wiki/Louis_Le_Prince "Louis Le Prince"), of a _[Roundhay Garden
Scene](/wiki/Roundhay_Garden_Scene "Roundhay Garden Scene")_ and of _[Leeds
Bridge](/wiki/Leeds_Bridge "Leeds Bridge")_ in 1888. These short film clips
can be found on YouTube.

[Thwaite Mills Watermill Museum](/wiki/Thwaite_Mills_Watermill_Museum "Thwaite
Mills Watermill Museum") is a fully restored 1820s water-powered mill on the
[River Aire](/wiki/River_Aire "River Aire") to the east of the city centre.
The [Thackray Museum](/wiki/Thackray_Museum "Thackray Museum") is a museum of
the history of medicine, featuring topics such as Victorian public health,
pre-anaesthesia surgery, and safety in childbirth. It is housed in a former
[workhouse](/wiki/Workhouse "Workhouse") next to [St James's
Hospital](/wiki/St_James%27s_University_Hospital,_Leeds "St James's University
Hospital, Leeds"). The [Royal Armouries Museum](/wiki/Royal_Armouries_Museum
"Royal Armouries Museum") opened in 1996 in a dramatic modern building when
this part of the national collection was transferred from the [Tower of
London](/wiki/Tower_of_London "Tower of London"). Nearby is the Leeds Museum
Discovery Centre (formerly housed at the Leeds Museum Resource Centre in
[Yeadon](/wiki/Yeadon,_West_Yorkshire "Yeadon, West Yorkshire"))[171] the
major storage of items not currently on display in museums, and open to the
public by appointment.[171][172]

[Leeds Art Gallery](/wiki/Leeds_Art_Gallery "Leeds Art Gallery") houses
important collections of traditional and contemporary British art. It is
closed for refurbishment until 13 October 2017.[173] Smaller museums in Leeds
include [Otley Museum](/wiki/Otley_Museum "Otley Museum");
[Horsforth](/wiki/Horsforth "Horsforth") Village Museum;[174] ULITA, an
Archive of International Textiles;[175] and the museum at [Fulneck Moravian
Settlement](/wiki/Fulneck_Moravian_Settlement "Fulneck Moravian Settlement").

### Music, theatre and
dance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section:
Music, theatre and dance")]

Main articles: [Music in Leeds](/wiki/Music_in_Leeds "Music in Leeds") and
[List of bands originating in Leeds](/wiki/List_of_bands_originating_in_Leeds
"List of bands originating in Leeds")

Leeds is home to the [Grand Theatre](/wiki/Grand_Theatre_Leeds "Grand Theatre
Leeds") where [Opera North](/wiki/Opera_North "Opera North") is based, this
establishment seats 1,500 people and has recently undergone a £31.5m
refurbishment. The [City Varieties](/wiki/Leeds_City_Varieties "Leeds City
Varieties") Music Hall, which hosted performances by [Charlie
Chaplin](/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin "Charlie Chaplin") and [Harry
Houdini](/wiki/Harry_Houdini "Harry Houdini") and was also the venue of the
BBC television programme _[The Good Old
Days](/wiki/The_Good_Old_Days_\(UK_TV_series\) "The Good Old Days \(UK TV
series\)")_ , and [West Yorkshire Playhouse](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Playhouse
"West Yorkshire Playhouse").[176][177][178] Just south of [Leeds
Bridge](/wiki/Leeds_Bridge "Leeds Bridge") once stood [The
Theatre](/wiki/The_Theatre,_Leeds "The Theatre, Leeds") which hosted [Sarah
Siddons](/wiki/Sarah_Siddons "Sarah Siddons") and [Ching Lau
Lauro](/wiki/Ching_Lau_Lauro "Ching Lau Lauro") in 1786 and 1834
respectively.[179][180]

Leeds is also home to [Phoenix Dance Theatre](/wiki/Phoenix_Dance_Theatre
"Phoenix Dance Theatre"), who were formed in the Harehills area of the city in
1981, and [Northern Ballet Theatre](/wiki/Northern_Ballet_Theatre "Northern
Ballet Theatre").[181] In autumn 2010 the two companies moved into a purpose-
built dance centre which is the largest space for dance outside London. It is
also the only space for dance to house a national classical and a national
contemporary dance company alongside each another.[182]

The [First Direct Arena](/wiki/First_Direct_Arena "First Direct Arena")[183]
opened in September 2013. The 13,500 seater stadium is rapidly becoming the
city's number one venue for live music, indoor sports and many other events.
Concerts are also held at the O2 Academy, Elland Road, which has hosted groups
such as Queen and Kaiser Chiefs, among others and at the universities.
[Roundhay Park](/wiki/Roundhay_Park "Roundhay Park") in north Leeds has seen
some of the world's biggest artists including [Michael
Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael Jackson"),
[Madonna](/wiki/Madonna_\(entertainer\) "Madonna \(entertainer\)"), [Bruce
Springsteen](/wiki/Bruce_Springsteen "Bruce Springsteen") and [Robbie
Williams](/wiki/Robbie_Williams "Robbie Williams").

Popular musical acts originating from Leeds include [Soft
Cell](/wiki/Soft_Cell "Soft Cell"), [Kaiser Chiefs](/wiki/Kaiser_Chiefs
"Kaiser Chiefs"), [The Pigeon Detectives](/wiki/The_Pigeon_Detectives "The
Pigeon Detectives"), [The Wedding Present](/wiki/The_Wedding_Present "The
Wedding Present"), [The Sunshine Underground](/wiki/The_Sunshine_Underground
"The Sunshine Underground"), [The Sisters of Mercy](/wiki/The_Sisters_of_Mercy
"The Sisters of Mercy"), [Hadouken!](/wiki/Hadouken! "Hadouken!"), [Corinne
Bailey Rae](/wiki/Corinne_Bailey_Rae "Corinne Bailey Rae"), [Dinosaur Pile-
Up](/wiki/Dinosaur_Pile-Up "Dinosaur Pile-Up"), [Pulled Apart By
Horses](/wiki/Pulled_Apart_By_Horses "Pulled Apart By Horses"), [Gang of
Four](/wiki/Gang_of_Four_\(band\) "Gang of Four \(band\)"),
[Hood](/wiki/Hood_\(band\) "Hood \(band\)"), [The Rhythm
Sisters](/wiki/The_Rhythm_Sisters "The Rhythm Sisters"), [Utah
Saints](/wiki/Utah_Saints "Utah Saints"), [Alt-J](/wiki/Alt-J "Alt-J") and
[Melanie B](/wiki/Melanie_B "Melanie B") of the [Spice
Girls](/wiki/Spice_Girls "Spice Girls").[184][185][186][187][188][189]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Leeds_First_Direct_Arena.jpg/220px-
The_Leeds_First_Direct_Arena.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Leeds_First_Direct_Arena.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Leeds_First_Direct_Arena.jpg "Enlarge")

Leeds [First Direct Arena](/wiki/First_Direct_Arena "First Direct Arena")

On [Valentine's Day](/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day "Valentine's Day"), 1970 [The
Who](/wiki/The_Who "The Who") performed and recorded their album _[Live at
Leeds](/wiki/Live_at_Leeds "Live at Leeds")_ at the [Leeds
University](/wiki/University_of_Leeds "University of Leeds") refectory. Since
its initial reception, _Live at Leeds_ has been cited by several [music
critics](/wiki/Music_journalism "Music journalism") as the best live rock
recording of all time.[190][191][192]

### Nightlife[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=31 "Edit
section: Nightlife")]

Leeds has the fourth largest student population in the country (over
200,000[193]), and is therefore one of the UK's hotspots for night-life. There
are a large number of pubs, bars, nightclubs and restaurants, as well as a
multitude of venues for live music. The full range of music tastes is catered
for in Leeds. It includes the original home of the famous club nights Back 2
Basics, Speedqueen and [Vague](/wiki/Vague_club,_Leeds "Vague club,
Leeds").[194] Morley was the location of [techno](/wiki/Techno "Techno") club
The Orbit.[195] Leeds has a number of large 'super-clubs' and there is a
selection of independent clubs such as [Club
Mission](/w/index.php?title=Club_Mission&action=edit&redlink=1 "Club Mission
\(page does not exist\)") and [Mint
Club](/w/index.php?title=Mint_Club&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mint Club \(page
does not exist\)"), which is consistently ranked as one of the world's best
clubs by DJ Magazine. Two other Leeds clubs, The Warehouse and The Garage
featured in the Top 100 Clubs list from 2013.[196]

Leeds has a well established gay nightlife scene. The Bridge Inn and [The New
Penny](/wiki/The_New_Penny "The New Penny"), both on [Call
Lane](/wiki/Call_Lane "Call Lane"), have long been gay night spots.[197]

Towards [Millennium Square](/wiki/Millennium_Square_\(Leeds\) "Millennium
Square \(Leeds\)") and the Civic or Northern Quarter, is a growing
entertainment district providing for both students and weekend visitors. The
square has many bars and restaurants and a large outdoor screen. Millennium
Square is a venue for large seasonal events such as a [Christmas
market](/wiki/Christmas_market "Christmas market"), gigs and concerts,
citywide parties and the Rhythms of the City Festival. It is adjacent to the
Mandela Gardens, which were opened by [Nelson Mandela](/wiki/Nelson_Mandela
"Nelson Mandela") in 2001. A number of public art features, fountains, a canal
and greenery can be found here.

Yorkshire has a great history of real ale,[198] but several bars near the
railway station are fusing traditional beers with a modern bar. Popular bars
such as this include The Hop, The Cross Keys and The Brewery Tap.

The city has teams representing all the major national sports. [Leeds United
F.C.](/wiki/Leeds_United_F.C. "Leeds United F.C.") is the city's main
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") club. [Leeds
Rhinos](/wiki/Leeds_Rhinos "Leeds Rhinos") ([Rugby League](/wiki/Rugby_League
"Rugby League")), [Leeds Carnegie](/wiki/Leeds_Carnegie "Leeds Carnegie")
([Rugby Union](/wiki/Rugby_Union "Rugby Union")) and [Yorkshire County Cricket
Club](/wiki/Yorkshire_County_Cricket_Club "Yorkshire County Cricket Club") are
also based in the city.

[Leeds United](/wiki/Leeds_United_F.C. "Leeds United F.C.") was formed in 1919
and plays at the 37,890 capacity [Elland Road](/wiki/Elland_Road "Elland
Road") stadium in [Beeston](/wiki/Beeston,_Leeds "Beeston, Leeds"). The team
plays in [The Championship](/wiki/The_Championship "The Championship") but has
enjoyed success at the highest level in the past, notably during the 1960s,
and 1970s when it won two [Football League](/wiki/Football_League "Football
League") titles, an [FA Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup"), a [Football League
Cup](/wiki/Football_League_Cup "Football League Cup") and an [Inter-Cities
Fairs Cup](/wiki/Inter-Cities_Fairs_Cup "Inter-Cities Fairs Cup") under the
management of [Don Revie](/wiki/Don_Revie "Don Revie"). The club's only other
major trophy to date came in 1992 when it won another top division title under
the management of [Howard Wilkinson](/wiki/Howard_Wilkinson "Howard
Wilkinson") – the last top division title of the Football League before the
creation of the [FA Premier League](/wiki/FA_Premier_League "FA Premier
League"), in which Leeds would play for 12 years before being relegated.

[Leeds Rhinos](/wiki/Leeds_Rhinos "Leeds Rhinos") are the most successful
[rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") team in Leeds. In 2009 they
became first club to be [Super League](/wiki/Super_League "Super League")
champions three seasons running, giving them their fourth Super League
title.[199] They play their home games at the [Headingley Carnegie
Stadium](/wiki/Headingley_Stadium "Headingley Stadium").
[Hunslet](/wiki/Hunslet_R.L.F.C. "Hunslet R.L.F.C.") (previously
[Hunslet](/wiki/Hunslet_F.C._\(1883\) "Hunslet F.C. \(1883\)")), based at the
[John Charles Centre for Sport](/wiki/John_Charles_Centre_for_Sport "John
Charles Centre for Sport") play in [Co-Operative Championship One](/wiki/Co-
operative_Championship "Co-operative Championship"). [East
Leeds](/wiki/East_Leeds_A.R.L.F.C. "East Leeds A.R.L.F.C.") and [Oulton
Raiders](/wiki/Oulton_Raiders "Oulton Raiders") play in the [National
Conference League](/wiki/National_Conference_League "National Conference
League"). [Bramley Buffaloes](/wiki/Bramley_Buffaloes "Bramley Buffaloes")
(previously [Bramley](/wiki/Bramley_RLFC "Bramley RLFC")), and [Leeds
Akkies](/wiki/Leeds_Akkies "Leeds Akkies") were members of the [Rugby League
Conference](/wiki/Rugby_League_Conference "Rugby League Conference").

[Yorkshire Carnegie](/wiki/Yorkshire_Carnegie "Yorkshire Carnegie"), formerly
known as _Leeds Tykes_ and _Leeds Carnegie_ , are the foremost [rugby
union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") team in Leeds and they play at
[Headingley Carnegie Stadium](/wiki/Headingley_Stadium "Headingley Stadium").
They play in the [RFU Championship](/wiki/RFU_Championship "RFU Championship")
having been relegated from The Guinness Premiership at the end of the 2010–11
season. [Otley R.U.F.C.](/wiki/Otley_R.U.F.C. "Otley R.U.F.C.") are a rugby
union club based to the north of the city and compete in [National League 2
North](/wiki/National_League_2_North "National League 2 North"), whilst
[Morley R.F.C.](/wiki/Morley_R.F.C. "Morley R.F.C."), located in
[Morley](/wiki/Morley,_West_Yorkshire "Morley, West Yorkshire") currently play
in [National Division Three North](/wiki/National_Division_Three_North
"National Division Three North").

[Headingley](/wiki/Headingley "Headingley") stadium is home to [Yorkshire
County Cricket Club](/wiki/Yorkshire_County_Cricket_Club "Yorkshire County
Cricket Club") which is the most successful [cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket")
team in England, with over 31 [County Championship](/wiki/County_Championship
"County Championship") wins. Their main rivals are
[Lancashire](/wiki/Lancashire "Lancashire").

[Leeds United L.F.C.](/wiki/Leeds_United_L.F.C. "Leeds United L.F.C.") are the
best-placed [women's football](/wiki/Women%27s_association_football "Women's
association football") team in Leeds, competing at the highest level in
[England](/wiki/Women%27s_football_in_England "Women's football in England"),
the [FA Women's Premier League National
Division](/wiki/FA_Women%27s_Premier_League_National_Division "FA Women's
Premier League National Division"). Leeds City Athletic Club competes in the
[British Athletics League](/wiki/British_Athletics_League "British Athletics
League") and UK Women's League as well as the Northern Athletics League.

Leeds is home to a number of [field hockey](/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey")
clubs that compete in the [North Hockey League](/wiki/North_Hockey_Association
"North Hockey Association"), [Yorkshire Hockey Association
League](/wiki/Yorkshire_Hockey_Association "Yorkshire Hockey Association") and
[BUCS leagues](/wiki/British_Universities_and_Colleges_Sport "British
Universities and Colleges Sport"). These include Leeds Hockey Club, [Leeds
Adel Carnegie Hockey Club](/wiki/Leeds_Adel_Carnegie_Hockey_Club "Leeds Adel
Carnegie Hockey Club"), the [University of Leeds](/wiki/University_of_Leeds
"University of Leeds") Hockey Club and [Leeds Beckett
University](/wiki/Leeds_Beckett_University "Leeds Beckett University") Hockey
Club.[200][201][202][203][204] Leeds Hockey Club Men's 1s gained promotion at
the end of the 2016/2017 season to become Leeds' first hockey team competing
in a National League.[205]

The City of Leeds Synchronised Swimming Club[206] train at the [John Charles
Centre for Sport](/wiki/John_Charles_Centre_for_Sport "John Charles Centre for
Sport") and are represented by swimmers throughout the whole of the North
East. The club was founded in 2008 and only compete in National and
International Competition.

The city has a wealth of sports facilities including the [Elland
Road](/wiki/Elland_Road "Elland Road") football stadium, a host stadium during
the [1996 European Football
Championship](/wiki/1996_European_Football_Championship "1996 European
Football Championship"); the [Headingley Carnegie
Stadiums](/wiki/Headingley_Stadium "Headingley Stadium"), adjacent stadia
world-famous for both [cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket") and [rugby
league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") and the [John Charles Centre for
Sport](/wiki/John_Charles_Centre_for_Sport "John Charles Centre for Sport")
with an [Olympic sized pool](/wiki/List_of_Olympic-
size_swimming_pools_in_the_United_Kingdom "List of Olympic-size swimming pools
in the United Kingdom") in its Aquatics Centre[207] and includes a multi-use
stadium. Other facilities include the Leeds Wall (climbing) and Yeadon Tarn
sailing centre. In 1929 the first Ryder Cup of Golf to be held on British soil
was competed for at the Moortown Golf club in Leeds and Wetherby has a
[National Hunt](/wiki/National_Hunt "National Hunt")
[racecourse](/wiki/Wetherby_Racecourse "Wetherby Racecourse").[208] In the
period 1928 to 1939 speedway racing was staged in Leeds on a track at the
greyhound stadium known as Fullerton Park, adjacent to Elland Road. The track
entered a team in the 1931 Northern league.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Leeds_Rhinos_vs._Salford_Red_Devils%2C_Headingley_Stadium_%2821st_April_2014%29_013.JPG/220px-
Leeds_Rhinos_vs._Salford_Red_Devils%2C_Headingley_Stadium_%2821st_April_2014%29_013.JPG)](/wiki/File:Leeds_Rhinos_vs._Salford_Red_Devils,_Headingley_Stadium_\(21st_April_2014\)_013.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_Rhinos_vs._Salford_Red_Devils,_Headingley_Stadium_\(21st_April_2014\)_013.JPG
"Enlarge")

Headingley Stadium, home of the [Leeds Rhinos](/wiki/Leeds_Rhinos "Leeds
Rhinos").

The [2014 Tour de France](/wiki/2014_Tour_de_France "2014 Tour de France")
Grand Départ took place from the Headrow in Leeds city centre on 5 July 2014.

Leeds is well known for its divers and features some of the best diving
facilities in the UK. _City of Leeds Diving Club_ who train at the [John
Charles Centre for Sport](/wiki/John_Charles_Centre_for_Sport "John Charles
Centre for Sport") has trained many athletes who have competed at
international and [Olympic](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games") level, with
[Jack Laugher](/wiki/Jack_Laugher "Jack Laugher") and [Chris
Mears](/wiki/Chris_Mears_\(diver\) "Chris Mears \(diver\)") making history by
becoming the first ever divers from Great Britain to win an Olympic gold
medal, a feat they accomplished at the [2016 Rio
Olympics](/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics "2016 Summer Olympics").

## Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=34 "Edit
section: Religion")]

See also: [List of places of worship in the City of
Leeds](/wiki/List_of_places_of_worship_in_the_City_of_Leeds "List of places of
worship in the City of Leeds")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/St_Peter%2C_Leeds_%28Leeds_Parish_Church%29_%285373648288%29.jpg/220px-
St_Peter%2C_Leeds_%28Leeds_Parish_Church%29_%285373648288%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Peter,_Leeds_\(Leeds_Parish_Church\)_\(5373648288\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:St_Peter,_Leeds_\(Leeds_Parish_Church\)_\(5373648288\).jpg
"Enlarge")

[Leeds Minster](/wiki/Leeds_Minster "Leeds Minster")

The majority of people in Leeds identify themselves as Christian.[72] Leeds
does not have a [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of
England") Cathedral: it is in the [Anglican](/wiki/Anglicanism "Anglicanism")
[Diocese of Leeds](/wiki/Anglican_Diocese_of_Leeds "Anglican Diocese of
Leeds") (formerly in the [Diocese of Ripon and
Leeds](/wiki/Diocese_of_Ripon_and_Leeds "Diocese of Ripon and Leeds")), headed
by the [Bishop of Leeds](/wiki/Anglican_Bishop_of_Leeds "Anglican Bishop of
Leeds"), which has cathedrals in [Bradford](/wiki/Bradford_Cathedral "Bradford
Cathedral"), [Ripon](/wiki/Ripon_Cathedral "Ripon Cathedral") and
[Wakefield](/wiki/Wakefield_Cathedral "Wakefield Cathedral") although the
[Bishop](/wiki/Bishop_of_Ripon_and_Leeds "Bishop of Ripon and Leeds")'s
residence has been in Leeds since 2008. The most important Anglican church is
[Leeds Minster](/wiki/Leeds_Minster "Leeds Minster"), although [St.
George's](/wiki/St_George%27s_Church,_Leeds "St George's Church, Leeds") has
the largest congregation by far.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Leeds
has a Roman Catholic [Cathedral](/wiki/Leeds_Cathedral "Leeds Cathedral"), the
[Episcopal](/wiki/Bishop "Bishop") seat of the [Roman Catholic Diocese of
Leeds](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Leeds "Roman Catholic Diocese of
Leeds"). Many other Christian denominations and new religious movements are
established in Leeds, including [Assemblies of God](/wiki/Assemblies_of_God
"Assemblies of God"), [Baptist](/wiki/Baptist_Union_of_Great_Britain "Baptist
Union of Great Britain"), [Christian
Scientist](/wiki/Church_of_Christ,_Scientist "Church of Christ, Scientist"),
[Latter-day Saints](/wiki/Latter-day_Saints "Latter-day Saints")
("[LDS](/wiki/LDS_Church "LDS Church")" or "[Mormon](/wiki/Mormonism
"Mormonism")"), [Community of Christ](/wiki/Community_of_Christ "Community of
Christ"), [Greek Orthodox](/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church "Greek Orthodox
Church"), [Jehovah's Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's
Witnesses"), [Jesus Army](/wiki/Jesus_Army "Jesus Army"),
[Lutheran](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism"),
[Methodist](/wiki/Methodist_Church_of_Great_Britain "Methodist Church of Great
Britain"), [Moravian](/wiki/Moravian_Church "Moravian Church"),
[Nazarene](/wiki/Church_of_the_Nazarene "Church of the Nazarene"),
[Newfrontiers](/wiki/Newfrontiers "Newfrontiers"),
[Pentecostal](/wiki/Pentecostalism "Pentecostalism"), [Salvation
Army](/wiki/The_Salvation_Army "The Salvation Army"), [Seventh-day
Adventist](/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church "Seventh-day Adventist Church"),
[Society of Friends ("Quakers")](/wiki/Religious_Society_of_Friends "Religious
Society of Friends"),
[Unitarian](/wiki/General_Assembly_of_Unitarian_and_Free_Christian_Churches
"General Assembly of Unitarian and Free Christian Churches"), [United
Reformed](/wiki/United_Reformed_Church "United Reformed Church"),
[Vineyard](/wiki/Association_of_Vineyard_Churches "Association of Vineyard
Churches"), [Wesleyan](/wiki/Methodist_Church_of_Great_Britain "Methodist
Church of Great Britain"), an ecumenical Chinese church, [Winners'
Chapel](/wiki/Winners%27_Chapel "Winners' Chapel") and several independent
churches.[209][210]

HarehillsMosqueDome.jpg)](/wiki/File:HarehillsMosqueDome.jpg)

Harehills Mosque

The proportion of [Muslims](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") in Leeds is slightly above
average for the country (5.4% as of 2011).[72] Mosques can be found throughout
the city, serving Muslim communities in
[Chapeltown](/wiki/Chapeltown,_West_Yorkshire "Chapeltown, West Yorkshire"),
[Harehills](/wiki/Harehills "Harehills"), [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_Leeds
"Hyde Park, Leeds") and parts of [Beeston](/wiki/Beeston,_Leeds "Beeston,
Leeds"). The largest mosque is [Leeds Grand Mosque](/wiki/Leeds_Grand_Mosque
"Leeds Grand Mosque") in Hyde Park.

The [Sikh](/wiki/Sikhism "Sikhism") community is represented by
[gurudwaras](/wiki/Gurudwara "Gurudwara") (temples) spread across the city,
the largest being in [Chapeltown](/wiki/Chapeltown,_West_Yorkshire
"Chapeltown, West Yorkshire"). There is also a colourful religious annual
procession, called the Nagar Kirtan, into [Millennium
Square](/wiki/Millennium_Square,_Leeds "Millennium Square, Leeds") in the city
centre on 13–14 April to celebrate [Vaisakhi](/wiki/Vaisakhi "Vaisakhi") – the
Sikh New Year and the birth of the religion. It is estimated that around 3,000
Sikhs in Leeds take part in this annual event.

Leeds' [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish "Jewish") community is the third-largest in the
United Kingdom[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], after London and Greater Manchester. The areas
of [Alwoodley](/wiki/Alwoodley "Alwoodley") and
[Moortown](/wiki/Moortown,_West_Yorkshire "Moortown, West Yorkshire") contain
sizeable Jewish populations.[73] There are eight active synagogues in
Leeds.[211]

The [Hindu](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") community in Leeds has a
[temple](/wiki/Hindu_temple "Hindu temple") (mandir) at [Hyde
Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_Leeds "Hyde Park, Leeds").[212] The temple has all the
major Hindu deities and is dedicated to the Lord [Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira
"Mahavira") of the [Jains](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism").[213]

Various [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") traditions are represented in
Leeds,[214] including: [Soka Gakkai](/wiki/Soka_Gakkai "Soka Gakkai"),
[Theravada](/wiki/Theravada "Theravada"), [Tibetan](/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism
"Tibetan Buddhism"), [Triratna Buddhist
Community](/wiki/Triratna_Buddhist_Community "Triratna Buddhist Community")
and [Zen](/wiki/Zen "Zen"). The Buddhist community
([sangha](/wiki/Sangha_\(Buddhism\) "Sangha \(Buddhism\)")) comes together to
celebrate the major festival of [Wesak](/wiki/Vesak "Vesak") in May.

There is also a community of the [Bahai
Faith](/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith_in_England "Bahá'í Faith in England") in
Leeds.[215]

## Public services[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Leeds&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Public services")]

Water supply and sewerage services in Leeds are provided by [Yorkshire
Water](/wiki/Yorkshire_Water "Yorkshire Water"), part of the [Kelda
Group](/wiki/Kelda_Group "Kelda Group"). Prior to 1973 it had been provided by
the Leeds Corporation. Leeds City Council has a target of 11MW of renewable
energy from onshore wind by 2010 and an aspirational target of 75MW by 2020.
There are currently no operational wind farms in Leeds, but a planning
application by [Banks Renewables Ltd](/wiki/Banks_Renewables_Ltd "Banks
Renewables Ltd") for five turbines at Hook Moor near
[Micklefield](/wiki/Micklefield "Micklefield") was approved in 2011.[216]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Leeds_central_library_001.jpg/220px-
Leeds_central_library_001.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leeds_central_library_001.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leeds_central_library_001.jpg "Enlarge")

Leeds Central Library.

The area is policed by the [West Yorkshire Police](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Police
"West Yorkshire Police"). The force has five policing districts covering the
West Yorkshire area, one of which covers Leeds. The Leeds District
Headquarters is located at Elland Road in the South of the City. In the North
West of the City the main stations are [Weetwood](/wiki/Weetwood "Weetwood")
and Woodhouse Lane; in the North East the main stations are Stainbeck near
[Chapel Allerton](/wiki/Chapel_Allerton "Chapel Allerton") and
[Killingbeck](/wiki/Killingbeck "Killingbeck"); in the South the main stations
are Leeds Central located on Park Street in the city centre and the District
Headquarters itself. Fire and rescue services are provided by the [West
Yorkshire Fire and Rescue
Service](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Fire_and_Rescue_Service "West Yorkshire Fire and
Rescue Service"). The fire stations in Leeds are: [Cookridge](/wiki/Cookridge
"Cookridge"), [Gipton](/wiki/Gipton "Gipton"), [Hunslet](/wiki/Hunslet
"Hunslet"), [Stanks](/wiki/Stanks "Stanks"),
[Moortown](/wiki/Moortown,_West_Yorkshire "Moortown, West Yorkshire"),
[Stanningley](/wiki/Stanningley "Stanningley") and the "Leeds" fire station
(near city centre, on Kirkstall Road).

Health services are provided by the [Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS
Trust](/wiki/Leeds_Teaching_Hospitals_NHS_Trust "Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS
Trust"), Leeds Primary Care Trust[217] and Leeds and York Partnership NHS
Foundation Trust[218][219] which provides mental health services. [Leeds
General Infirmary](/wiki/Leeds_General_Infirmary "Leeds General Infirmary")
("LGI") is a [listed building](/wiki/Listed_building "Listed building") with
more recent additions and is in the city centre. [St James's University
Hospital](/wiki/St_James%27s_University_Hospital "St James's University
Hospital"), known locally as "Jimmy's"[220][221] is to the north east of the
city centre and is the largest teaching hospital in Europe. Other NHS
hospitals are [Chapel Allerton Hospital](/wiki/Chapel_Allerton_Hospital
"Chapel Allerton Hospital"), [Seacroft Hospital](/wiki/Seacroft_Hospital
"Seacroft Hospital"), [Wharfedale Hospital](/wiki/Wharfedale_Hospital
"Wharfedale Hospital") in Otley, and Leeds Dental Institute. The new NHS Leeds
Website provides information on NHS services in Leeds.[222]

[West Yorkshire Joint Services](/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Joint_Services "West
Yorkshire Joint Services") provides analytical, archaeological, archives,
ecology, materials testing and trading standards services in Leeds and the
other four districts of West Yorkshire. It was created following the abolition
of the county council in 1986 and expanded in 1997, and is funded by the five
district councils, pro rata to their population. The Leeds site of the
archives service is in the former public library at
[Sheepscar](/wiki/Sheepscar "Sheepscar"), Leeds.[223]

[Leeds City Council](/wiki/Leeds_City_Council "Leeds City Council") is
responsible for over 50 public libraries across the whole city, including 5
mobile libraries. The main [Central Library](/wiki/Leeds_Central_Library
"Leeds Central Library") is located on the [Headrow](/wiki/Headrow "Headrow")
in the city centre.
